lead_paragraph: When Ron Boire was growing up on a dairy farm in upstate New York, helping out around the property for $2 an hour, he saw new books as an out-of-reach luxury.

headline: Review: After the Terrors of the Blitz Comes ‘A Royal Night Out’
abstract: In this fantasy directed by Julian Jarrold, two princesses escape, incognito, to commune with the joyful masses on the day Word War II ended in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The aggressively charming “A Royal Night Out,” is a grown-up fairy tale for audiences whose hearts go pitter-pat at the mere mention of anything to do with the British royal family. Sorry to be a spoilsport, reader, but my heart sinks at the sight of people bowing and scraping before aristocrats with titles they haven’t earned. It all seems so silly.

headline: ‘Origami Heaven’ Unfolds
abstract: An exhibition of folded and cut paper at Stony Brook University shows a simple craft transformed into high art.
lead_paragraph: At first, Kumi Yamashita’s work “Origami” looks like nothing more than brightly colored squares of paper, each slightly crumpled along one edge, arranged on a white wall. And then you notice the shadow that each paper casts — the profile of a face, each one unique.

headline: Avon Said to Be in Talks to Sell North American Business
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The beauty company has been in negotiations with Cerberus Capital Management for the past few months.
lead_paragraph: Avon Products is in discussions to sell its North American business, where its army of Avon ladies first called, to a tough-nosed private equity firm as part of the cosmetics maker’s efforts to turn around its fortunes, people with direct knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Illinois: Chicago to Release Second Police Video
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Under pressure after the release of video of a white officer shooting a black teenager, Mayor Rahm Emanuel, in a shift, said that the city would release video from another police shooting.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure after the release of video of a white police officer shooting a black teenager, Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said Thursday that the city would reverse course in a separate case and release video from another police shooting that it had fought to keep private. The family of Ronald Johnson has called for the police dashboard video from his fatal shooting to be made public, saying it will show that he was unarmed and moving away from officers when he was shot in the back. The police have said that Mr. Johnson, 25, pointed a weapon at officers. The shooting occurred on Oct. 12, 2014, eight days before the shooting of the teenager, Laquan McDonald, whose death was captured on a video that has outraged residents and led to the firing of the city’s police superintendent.

headline: Review: Sorrentino’s ‘Youth’: A Euro Buddy Film
abstract: Michael Caine and Harvey Keitel, playing a composer and a filmmaker, look back on their long friendship from the perspective of an exclusive Alpine retreat.
lead_paragraph: The setting of “Youth,” Paolo Sorrentino’s new film, is an Alpine resort — a picturesque place rich with cultural associations and full of rich, cultured guests. Even if most people in the audience have never been to such a spot, it may nonetheless ring a few bells and jog some literary and cinematic memories. We’ve been here before. Was it “The Magic Mountain” or “The Grand Budapest Hotel”? “The Good Soldier”? “Last Year at Marienbad”?

headline: Texas: Parole Denied for Transgender Inmate
keywords: ['Probation and Parole', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Passion Star, a black transgender woman who has served 13 years in men’s prisons, was denied parole last week.
lead_paragraph: Passion Star, a black transgender woman who has served 13 years in men’s prisons, was denied parole last week. The Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles cited the nature of her offense, although her co-defendant — also convicted of aggravated kidnapping and sentenced to 20 years — was released over two years ago. Noting that the co-defendant was white and “not transgender,” Lambda Legal, the group that represents Ms. Star, said it found the disparity a troubling illustration of “the injustice that runs throughout the criminal system.” Ms. Star, 32, was the subject of an article about prison rape in The New York Times; she is suing corrections officials for failing to protect her against sexual victimization.

headline: Kazakhstan Moves to Tighten Control of Internet Traffic
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The country’s government wants Internet users to use a digital certificate that could allow officials to monitor encrypted communications.
lead_paragraph: Government officials in Kazakhstan are borrowing a page from China, quietly devising their own version of China’s so-called Great Firewall to unscramble encrypted web and mobile traffic as it flows in and out of Kazakh borders.

headline: At Eastern Connecticut Ballet School, a Link to Balanchine’s ‘Nutcracker’
abstract: Gloria Govrin, who worked with George Balanchine for 15 years, has been preparing a new generation of dancers for their staging of the holiday ballet.
lead_paragraph: In a sunlit dance studio on a recent Saturday, Gloria Govrin, draped in black clothes and wearing soft leather shoes that made her appear barefoot, gracefully demonstrated a dance sequence to a young ballerina. They were the steps that marked the entrance of Coffee, the slinky, Arabian dance character who appears in Act Two of “The Nutcracker.”

headline: Review: Chronicling an Outsider in ‘Almost There’
abstract: This documentary from Dan Rybicky and Aaron Wickenden follows the story of Peter Anton, an artist in Indiana.
lead_paragraph: “I think as a journalist — I don’t think as a filmmaker,” one interviewee says, almost off-handedly, late into “Almost There.” This first feature from Dan Rybicky and Aaron Wickenden demonstrates that these documentary filmmakers might do well to think more like journalists sometimes.

headline: Review: In ‘Krampus,’ the Holiday Involves a Demonic Santa
abstract: A family, stressed over the holidays, unleashes the wrath of Santa’s “shadow,” a demon won comes “to punish.”
lead_paragraph: Occasionally funny, intermittently scary, but mostly hectic and sloppy, “Krampus” tries very hard to be a different kind of Christmas movie. It wants to have its store-bought fruitcake and eat it too, to satirize the meanness and materialism of holiday-observing Americans and also connect with the vaguely defined real meaning of the season.

headline: U.S. Media Mocked Abroad for Reporting False Name of California Shooting Suspect
keywords: ['Hoaxes and Pranks', 'News and News Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)']
abstract: Major American news outlets, including The Los Angeles Times and Fox News, were ridiculed on Thursday for apparently falling victim to a hoax.
lead_paragraph: Major American news outlets, including The Los Angeles Times and Fox News, were ridiculed online on Thursday for apparently falling victim to a hoax as they reported that a suspect in the deadly shooting rampage in San Bernardino, Calif., had been identified as Tayyeep Bin Ardogan, 28, of Qatar.

headline: Lifting Their Voices, and Spirits, at a Bronx Nursing Home
abstract: The Glee Club at the Hebrew Home at Riverdale is releasing “Music Brings Us Together,” an album of show tunes and old standards sung by the group’s 20 members, who range in age from 79 to 100.
lead_paragraph: Muriel Palley has been a shower singer for as long as she can remember.

headline: At the Rye Arts Center, Learning New Ways of Creating
abstract: The institution, following the lead of major college-level art schools, offers children as young as 8 classes in coding, 3-D printing, computer animation, robotics and even Minecraft.
lead_paragraph: Julian Clemente sits at a laptop in a 3-D printing class at the Rye Arts Center, using the track pad to design a geometric container. A freckled 10-year-old with a mop of red hair, he stretches the squat cylinder with a virtual dragging tool, making it taller on the digital graphing paper. Now it resembles a vase. He spins the on-screen design, then flips it upside down to see if all the sides are even.

headline: JPMorgan Wrote Complaints After Firing a Whistle-Blower
keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mutual Funds', 'Financial Planners', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Clients of the broker, Johnny Burris, say a JPMorgan Chase employee wrote the complaints attributed to them and which were filed with the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Burris, a former broker at JPMorgan Chase, might have known he was walking into a minefield when he decided to go public with his concerns about his former employer.

headline: Review: ‘Bikes vs Cars’ Explores the Debate in Cyclist-Friendly Cities
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: From a cabdriver in Copenhagen to an activist in São Paulo, Fredrik Gertten’s documentary presents a wide range of viewpoints.
lead_paragraph: Breezy, intelligent, diffuse but uncluttered, Fredrik Gertten’s documentary “Bikes vs Cars” could be called a tale of congestion-plagued cities. The film, which examines the high cost that urban centers, especially Los Angeles and São Paulo, Brazil, pay for accommodating automobiles, benefits greatly from a range of viewpoints. Though its most persuasive speakers are politically involved bicyclists, car enthusiasts receive screen time as well.

headline: Tribute and a Reunion for Dick Cheney in Capital
keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Former President George W. Bush led the many Republicans attending the unveiling of a bust of his vice president; few Democrats were there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before making a rare return visit to the nation’s capital on Thursday, former President George W. Bush said he mentioned to his father that he would be attending a ceremony honoring his vice president, Dick Cheney.

headline: Chris Froome Releases Test Results but Does Little to Silence His Critics
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Doping (Sports)', 'Tests (Drug Use)', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Froome, a British cyclist whose two Tour de France wins drew doping allegations, released tests arranged by his wife in an article in the British edition of Esquire magazine.
lead_paragraph: In a bid to silence critics who claim that his two Tour de France wins were products of either conventional or so-called mechanical doping, Chris Froome on Thursday released results of several physiological tests that demonstrated he was in top physical condition.

headline: Joseph F. Girzone, Who Created Christlike Figure in ‘Joshua’ Novels, Dies at 85
abstract: Father Girzone sold his first books about Joshua, a modern-day Christlike figure, from the trunk of his car.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Joseph F. Girzone, a retired Roman Catholic priest whose popular inspirational novels starring a Christlike figure named Joshua were lauded and condemned in equal measure for their theological perspective, died on Nov. 29 in Albany. He was 85.

headline: Testimony at Trial Details No-Show Job of Dean Skelos’s Son
abstract: Anthony Bonomo testified that he was afraid to fire Adam Skelos, 33, from his $78,000-a-year job because it might upset his father, who at the time was the State Senate majority leader.
lead_paragraph: Writing a performance review can be a tricky, thankless task, but few posed the quandary that senior management at Physicians’ Reciprocal Insurers faced in June 2013: What should they say about Adam Skelos?

headline: Review: ‘Dementia,’ Where Misery Is Company
abstract: The titular illness is not the only disorder in the family of a Vietnam veteran who is recovering from a stroke.
lead_paragraph: Mike Testin has dozens of cinematography credits, but the psychological thriller “Dementia” is his first try at directing a feature. You’d never know it, though. It’s an assured, deftly acted movie that builds its creepiness slowly and keeps its secrets well hidden till the end.

headline: Review: In Wim Wenders’s ‘Every Thing Will Be Fine,’ Nothing Is
abstract: James Franco stars in this film about a emotionally detached writer who runs over a small child.
lead_paragraph: Something is off with “Every Thing Will Be Fine.” Even for a movie about a writer detached from his emotions, it’s ponderous, like a lucid dream gone bad.

headline: To Crush ISIS, John Kerry Urges Deft Removal of Syria’s Assad
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The secretary of state said he believed that if President Bashar al-Assad was carefully removed, America, Russia and Syria’s rebel forces could easily defeat the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Secretary of State John Kerry said Thursday he believes that if an agreement can be reached to ease President Bashar al-Assad of Syria from power, a coalition of Americans, Russians and Syrian forces could wipe out the Islamic State “in a matter of literally months.”

headline: Restaurant Review: At the Wooden Spoon, Letting the Home Fires Burn
abstract: On the menu and at the tables, old-fashioned feelings preside at the Wooden Spoon in New Rochelle.
lead_paragraph: Despite its contemporary trappings — exposed, opaque lights snaking over steel rods on the ceiling, horizontal barn wood covering the lower parts of several walls, exposed brick running along another — there is something nostalgic about the Wooden Spoon, a six-month-old restaurant in New Rochelle.

headline: A Century Later, Jack Johnson Awaits a Nation’s Absolution
keywords: ['Boxing', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Over 100 years later, supporters of Johnson, boxing’s first black heavyweight champion, still seek a pardon for the fighter’s 1913 conviction on trumped-up charges.
lead_paragraph: Why is the United States still afraid of Jack Johnson?

headline: Wanting More Than a Veto and a Prayer After Mass Shootings
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control', 'Vetoes (US)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: In an era when the United States has had an average of one mass shooting or more every day, the country has become the land of the free and the brave, and the home of the futile gesture.
lead_paragraph: Any decent person might want to pitch in “thoughts and prayers” after a mass shooting, even if it is hard to keep up. (Did you offer thoughts and prayers for the nine people killed at Umpqua Community College in Oregon in October, or did that one slip by when the next news cycle arrived with yet another shooting?)

headline: Review: ‘The Messenger’ Documents Avian Struggles
abstract: This film by Su Rynard tracks the global environmental difficulties facing birds, suggesting that they presage trouble for the human race as well.
lead_paragraph: Jewel-colored birds flapping their wings in languid motion draw the viewer into this lush but ultimately grim assessment of our planet’s future: Climate change and development are altering habitats more rapidly than birds can adapt, and that doesn’t bode well for people.

headline: Restaurant Review: At True North, a Focus on Homemade
abstract: The Huntington Village, N.Y., restaurant offers an eclectic menu and an array of dishes, from small plates to big.
lead_paragraph: Finding one’s true north translates roughly to following the right path. In September, Paul Miranda, former executive chef of Swallow in Huntington and Montauk, continued along his chosen path by opening, with Stuart Kritz, the aptly named True North in Huntington Village.

headline: Review: An Exploration of Race and Class in ‘My Friend Victoria’
abstract: This adaptation of a 2004 Doris Lessing short story follows the life of a young black woman in contemporary Paris.
lead_paragraph: As drifting and dreamy as its searching heroine, “My Friend Victoria” takes a graceful but unsatisfying stroll through the life and longings of a young black woman in contemporary Paris.

headline: Leaving Iran’s Nuclear Past a Mystery
abstract: Iran’s rulers appear as unwilling to provide insight into past nuclear activity as they were before the deal limiting their nuclear-fuel production was struck.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The Iranian nuclear crisis began a decade ago when Tehran’s leaders refused to answer questions from international inspectors about evidence that a secret team of scientists, working in a complex organization that sprawled across military and university laboratories, were experimenting with the technology to build a nuclear weapon.

headline: Review: ‘Orion’ Tells an Elvis Tale
abstract: Jeanie Finlay’s documentary tracks the Presley sound-alike singer Jimmy Ellis, whose career took off after Presley’s death.
lead_paragraph: The story of Jimmy Ellis, a singer blessed and cursed with a voice that sounded too much like Elvis Presley’s, is strange and tragic, a piece of musical history that says worlds about the fickleness of fame and ends with a jolt that makes it even sadder. It’s deftly told in “Orion: The Man Who Would Be King,” a documentary by Jeanie Finlay.

headline: Where They Shared Their Working Hours, and Their Dying Moments
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A day after 14 colleagues in a county health department were murdered at their office, family and friends tried to make sense of a devastating loss.
lead_paragraph: Struck down at an office holiday party, almost all the victims of the mass shooting Wednesday in San Bernardino, Calif., were friends and colleagues. And in a notable difference from some other highly publicized rampages, some of them also knew their killer, Syed Rizwan Farook, who opened fire on the group with his wife, Tashfeen Malik, the authorities said.

headline: FIFA Case Upends Soccer Politics in Latin America
abstract: The latest round of indictments in the growing scandal enveloping the soccer world has sent shock waves through soccer heavyweights like Brazil and Argentina as well as smaller countries like Guatemala and Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — No one epitomizes the ups and downs of Brazilian soccer quite like Ricardo Teixeira.

headline: George Sakato, 94, Dies; Awarded Medal of Honor Long After It Was Denied
abstract: Mr. Sakato was the last survivor of the seven living Japanese-American veterans to whom tribute was paid more than a half a century after they fought gallantly for a nation that feared and loathed their people.
lead_paragraph: George T. Sakato didn’t think he would be much of a combat soldier. He was only 5 feet 4 inches tall, and he couldn’t hit the target on the rifle range in Army basic training.

headline: Review: In ‘The Wannabe,’ Drugs, Money and Aspirations to Join the Gotti Circle
abstract: This modest, assured and cautionary gangland character study starring Vincent Piazza and Patricia Arquette isn’t short on mob cred.
lead_paragraph: “Boardwalk Empire” fans can celebrate that “The Wannabe,” Nick Sandow’s modest, assured and cautionary gangland character study, has players they may have been missing (if not the post-World War I setting).

headline: Review: ‘Open Door’ Helps Open Alvin Ailey Season
abstract: This work, Ronald K. Brown’s sixth for the company, was the centerpiece of Ailey’s season-opening gala at City Center.
lead_paragraph: There’s always some risk when a dance company unveils a premiere, especially on gala night, when the crowd is full of donors. Will they like it? But that risk is lower when the choreographer is like an old friend of the company, with a knowledge of the dancers built up over years.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Chengdu 1 Palace, Getting Her Chili-Oil Fix
abstract: Now in a much larger, fancier space, Chengdu 1 Palace retains the fiery Sichuan dishes a critic was so fond of — and a few new options.
lead_paragraph: When Chengdu 1 restaurant in Cedar Grove closed last summer, I went into mourning.

headline: Steven Vogel, Biologist Who Studied How Things Move, Dies at 75
abstract: Professor Vogel’s research and writing on how living things move in air and water helped define and popularize a new scientific field, comparative biomechanics.
lead_paragraph: Steven Vogel, a biologist whose research and writing on how living things move in air and water helped define and popularize a new scientific field, comparative biomechanics, died on Nov. 24 in Durham, N.C. He was 75.

headline: Bush ‘Super PAC’ to ‘Tell Jeb’s Story’ in 15-Minute Documentary
abstract: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Bush, has produced the documentary featuring him and will release it online on Saturday and later show it on television.
lead_paragraph: Voters will soon get 15 unfiltered minutes of the Jeb Bush story.

headline: Fear in the Air, Americans Look Over Their Shoulders
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gun Control']
abstract: After the latest mass shooting, a wide swath of America’s populace finds itself engulfed in a collective fear, a fear tinged with confusion and exasperation.
lead_paragraph: The killings are happening too often. Bunched too close together. At places you would never imagine.

headline: Review: In ‘The World of Kanako,’ the Old Ultraviolence
abstract: Tetsuya Nakashima’s film about a father trying to rescue his teenage daughter from the Japanese underworld glories in its lurid bloodthirstiness.
lead_paragraph: Tetsuya Nakashima’s thriller “The World of Kanako” might be filed under what some cineastes call extreme cinema. But screen overkill — and I mean kill — is more like it.

headline: Review: In ‘Life,’ Photographing James Dean, the Rising Star
abstract: In Anton Corbijn’s drama, Robert Pattinson plays the photographer Dennis Stock on assignment a few months before Dean’s death.
lead_paragraph: Anton Corbijn’s “Life” is one of those Great Encounters in History dramas, the kind that seeks to recapture (and remythologize) a magic moment. In 1955, a photographer for Magnum, Dennis Stock, shadowed and snapped an ascendant James Dean for Life magazine, a few months before Dean died in a car accident. Mr. Corbijn picturesquely frames the back story to the shoot, but his muffled retelling drifts with Dane DeHaan’s murmurous impersonation of Dean and Robert Pattinson’s almost perversely listless turn as Stock.

headline: Does Motive Matter in Mass Shootings?
abstract: Does it matter whether victims are killed by a Muslim extremist or someone with other reasons to pull the trigger?

headline: Review: ‘The Letters,’ a Biopic of Mother Teresa
abstract: William Riead’s film follows this nun as she decides to work with the impoverished in Kolkata.
lead_paragraph: “The Letters” doesn’t preach to the converted, or to anyone else, for that matter. Instead, this fairly standard biopic about Mother Teresa tells its tale with a minimum of flourish, resisting most opportunities to grandstand. That’s not high praise, but it’s also not an insult.

headline: Review: In ‘Steel Hammer,’ a Man and a Train in a Race and a Legend
abstract: Four playwrights, three vocalists, the troupe Siti Company and the Bang on a Can All Stars interpret the folk tale of John Henry in this production.
lead_paragraph: Julia Wolfe’s galvanizing score — alternately clamorous, haunting, exhilarating and sometimes all three simultaneously — provides a sturdy musical spine for “Steel Hammer,” a theatrical meditation on the legend of John Henry being presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday.

headline: Fox Neighbor
abstract: The return of David J. Kahn.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We’ve discussed constructor signatures over the past few days, and I have to admit that seeing David J. Kahn’s byline occasionally sets off a knee-jerk response in me that sounds something like this: “Oh dear, who died?”

headline: The Right Stuff
abstract: The return of Martin Ashwood-Smith.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Poor Excuse For a Blogger Alert! Hi all, I apologize for the mix up, which delayed the blog for Martin Ashwood-Smith’s post and inadvertently published another one with spoilers. I was sick yesterday and messed this up. Additional apologies to Mr. Ashwood-Smith for delaying his post, and let’s just pretend you didn’t see the Saturday post, which comes out tonight.

headline: Review: In David Mamet’s ‘China Doll,’ Al Pacino as an Urban Warrior in Winter
abstract: No play opening on Broadway this fall has had a more fraught back story, though star power always guaranteed a commercial slam dunk.
lead_paragraph: No matter what his salary is, it seems safe to say that Christopher Denham is the most underpaid actor on Broadway. Mr. Denham — a young man with, I sincerely hope, a very resilient nervous system — is one of a cast of two in “China Doll,” the saggy new play by David Mamet that was finally opened to critics on Wednesday night at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, and he is onstage for almost the entire show.

headline: Review: ‘Dream/Killer,’ a Father’s Battle to Free His Son in a Wrongful Conviction
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: This documentary by Andrew Jenks looks at the imprisonment of Ryan Ferguson in the 2001 murder of a newspaper editor in Columbia, Mo.
lead_paragraph: I won’t reveal the end of “dream/killer,” but I will predict what you’ll feel after watching it: This documentary elicits large measures of incredulity, frustration and astonishment.

headline: Donald Trump and Ben Carson Face a Foreign Policy Test Before a Republican Jewish Group
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Mr. Trump and Mr. Carson gave meandering speeches to the Republican Jewish Coalition on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump and Ben Carson may not have reduced doubts about their seriousness as leaders and their understanding of global affairs on Thursday as they delivered meandering speeches to one of the country’s most influential Republican Jewish organizations.

headline: Dreaming of a Southern Life, but First, Her Education
abstract: Tomar Coke, whose depression began as a teenager, is raising two young sons with developmental disabilities and a newborn daughter by herself.
lead_paragraph: Moments of calm are rare and fleeting in Tomar Coke’s home in the Bronx. If her two sons are peacefully watching television or playing with action figures, getting along in any way, she knows a clash is imminent.

headline: Connecticut Craft Distillers Are in a Growth Spurt
abstract: The state has a number of small distilleries, with more on the way, making fruit brandies as well as rye whiskey, vodka, gin and bourbon.
lead_paragraph: On the list of Connecticut-made food and drink, already bulging with cheese, eggs, beer, beef and bacon (to name just a few), one category is often overlooked: handcrafted liquor.

headline: Automation Is a Job Engine, New Research Says
abstract: A new study finds that technology increases job growth in occupations: Rather than displacing employees, it changes the nature of their work.
lead_paragraph: The fear that technology is poised to kill jobs in unprecedented numbers is widely prevelent these days. Nothing is likely to ease that anxiety much, but a new research paper might prompt some second thoughts.

headline: An Officer Who Trained for the Worst and Faced It: ‘This Was Actually Happening’
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: When Lt. Mike Madden pulled up to the scene of what would be one of the worst massacres the United States has seen in years, his training kicked in.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — He had trained for active-shooter situations. He recalled the drills where trainers barraged officers with everything they could — sounds, bright lights, smells — to overwhelm them.

abstract: The Times dance critic reviewed the premiere of George Balanchine’s “The Nutcracker” in 1954. “It is not much of a ballet,” he wrote.
lead_paragraph: John Martin became the first full-time dance critic at a major American publication when he joined The New York Times in 1927. Before his appointment, music or theater critics wrote on dance, the stepchild of the arts, satisfying no one.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Dec. 4, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Chi-Raq,” “Creed” and “The Good Dinosaur.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Chi-Raq,” “Creed” and “The Good Dinosaur.”

abstract: When you consider the ingenious ways that marine creatures maneuver, you have to feel sorry for humans. Walking seems so, well, pedestrian.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved legislation on Thursday night that would repeal President Obama’s landmark health care law, a goal of Republicans since the law was adopted in March 2010.

headline: ‘Dietrich & Riefenstahl,’ by Karin Wieland
abstract: While Marlene Dietrich entertained Allied troops, Leni Riefenstahl was palling around with Hitler.
lead_paragraph: The German historian Karin Wieland buries useful information on the acknowledgments page of “Dietrich & Riefenstahl: Hollywood, Berlin, and a Century in Two Lives.” She reports that her original manuscript “contained at least three additional books” before her German editor set about pruning.

headline: ‘Frank Stella: A Retrospective,’ by Michael Auping
abstract: Underneath the play of Stella’s work is a fierce determination to avoid the pedestrian.
lead_paragraph: A professor I know teaches that a work of art will give clues to how it wants to be discussed: It will suggest whether to dwell on its sense or its structure, whether to meet it with passion or calculation.

headline: Aftermath of the Massacre in San Bernardino
abstract: Police officers sorted through evidence and mourners gathered after the shootings in San Bernardino, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Police officers sorted through evidence and mourners gathered after the shootings in San Bernardino, Calif.

headline: New York’s Week in Pictures: Dec. 4
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include a ceremony for birds, the trial of Sheldon Silver and a museum of feelings.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include a ceremony for birds, the trial of Sheldon Silver and a museum of feelings.

headline: Presidential Candidates on Gun Violence
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: All of the Democratic candidates want new gun laws, while nearly all Republicans are against additional restrictions they see as harmful to Second Amendment rights.
lead_paragraph: All of the Democratic candidates want new gun laws, while nearly all Republicans are against additional restrictions they see as harmful to Second Amendment rights.

headline: ‘Notorious RBG: The Life and Times of Ruth Bader Ginsburg’
abstract: The unlikely comparison to the rapper Notorious B.I.G. gave Ginsburg’s fans the perfect vehicle for turning her precise lawyerly voice into a cultural roar.
lead_paragraph: Clark Kent had Superman. Ruth Bader Ginsburg has Notorious R.B.G. For 80 of her 82 years, the Supreme Court justice was known for being brilliant, reserved and a little dry. Then in 2013, the Internet gave her a super-hip-nerd alter ego. On a Tumblr created by a law student, Shana Knizhnik, fans posted ­photoshopped tributes to Ginsburg. In one frequently shared image, she wore a crown with the caption “Can’t Spell Truth Without Ruth.” She also appeared as a bobblehead doll, a tattoo on a bicep, a decal on a fingernail, and a baby wearing a huge pair of glasses.

headline: Molly Crabapple’s ‘Drawing Blood’
abstract: Through the artist Crabapple’s eyes, we see 9/11, the excesses of the aughts boom and Occupy Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: As her fast-paced autobiography attests, the artist Molly Crabapple was a quintessential wild child, irrepressible, pouty and proud, born determined and angry. At 12, she discovered punk rock. At 17, she traveled to Europe alone, slept in the famous Shakespeare & Company bookshop in Paris, walked the streets of Fez with her sketch pad, an artist-­wanderer, claiming for herself the space formerly reserved for men.

headline: ‘Food Whore,’ by Jessica Tom
abstract: She was only a graduate student, but she had the power to make or break restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Please allow me to introduce Michael Saltz, a man of wealth and no taste. Not bad taste — no taste at all. One day he finds that he can no longer detect sour, salty, sweet and bitter. This is inconvenient because he is supposed to be the restaurant critic of The New York Times.

headline: ‘About Women,’ by Lisa Alther and Françoise Gilot
abstract: An American novelist and a French-born painter discuss the influence of war on their childhoods, the creative process, religion, the feminine mystique and more.
lead_paragraph: “About Women” should inaugurate a series in which accomplished women of different backgrounds talk candidly about their lives. This book pairs an American novelist, Lisa Alther, the author of “Kinflicks,” and a French-born painter, Françoise Gilot, the author of another masterpiece, “Life With Picasso.”

headline: ‘The 613,’ by Archie Rand
abstract: The author spent five years painting each of the 613 commandments in the Old Testament.
lead_paragraph: Let’s hear it, in the pages of this liberal, freethinking bastion of progress, for God.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: Bill Murray and company serenade the holidays; a heartbroken Christmas tree salesman searches for love; and Kristen Stewart collects another award for “Clouds of Sils Maria.”
lead_paragraph: Stream, sing along, repeat: Bill Murray and company serenade the holidays in “A Very Murray Christmas.” A heartbroken Christmas-tree salesman searches for love in Brooklyn. And Kristen Stewart adds another award to her mantel for “Clouds of Sils Maria.”

headline: ‘My History: A Memoir of Growing Up,’ by Antonia Fraser
abstract: The history of a writer’s love affair with her vocation, and her nostalgia for the childhood “wonderland” that engendered it.
lead_paragraph: When she arrived as a boarder at the Godolphin School in 1944, at the age of 12, Antonia Pakenham — who would grow up to be the novelist and historian Lady Antonia Fraser, Dame of the British Empire, mother of six, grandmother of 18, wife of the Tory M.P. Hugh Fraser and, later, wife of the playwright Harold Pinter — made the startling discovery that she was “not really a girl.” That is, having just spent four years learning Greek and Latin at a school for boys (mostly) called the Dragon, next door to her family’s home in Oxford, England, she excelled at ancient languages and at the knock-’em-sock-’em sport of rugby, but was completely unschooled in conventional girlish behavior. In her new memoir, “My History,” she recalls, “I was like Kipling’s Mowgli in ‘The Jungle Book,’ the feral child who had been brought up by wolves and had difficulty adjusting to existence among human beings.”

headline: Bee Wilson’s ‘First Bite: How We Learn to Eat’
abstract: “First Bite” argues that if we learned what and how to eat as babies, we can unlearn and relearn and actually change our relationships with food.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, the British food journalist Bee Wilson automatically craved something indulgent before boarding a train. In “First Bite: How We Learn to Eat,” she traces this instinct to a ritual she had with her father when she was a teenager. Her parents had just split up, and whenever her dad would send Wilson on a train back to her mother’s house, he’d buy her a magazine and a box of chocolate-coated malted milk balls, something that, before her parents’ divorce, would have been deemed a special-occasion treat. She felt powerless to refuse the candy, even as she was struggling with a disconcerting weight gain. It took Wilson years to realize that her father’s gesture was as much about making him feel like “the generous provider” as it was to reward her with a happy sugar high. She writes: “To give a child the things she loves to eat bestows a heroic glow. It feels almost as wonderful as eating.”

headline: ‘Chapter and Verse: New Order, Joy Division and Me,’ by Bernard Sumner
abstract: Sumner’s memoir has the mild-­mannered charms of his vocals — clumsy, earnest, endearingly tongue-tied.
lead_paragraph: The glamorous rock-star life, circa 1983: The gawky Manchester kids in New Order visit the legendary New York disco Funhouse to shoot a video for their new single, “Confusion.” They hang with their producer, Arthur Baker, and the superstar D.J. Jellybean Benitez, watching from the booth while the crowd moves. It’s poignant how dazed New Order looks in this video — a couple of years earlier, they were your basic mopey indie twits, and here they are making the scene as their music plays at the world’s hippest dance club. Yet the most poignant sight is that of the singer Bernard Sumner, who spends the first half of the clip wearing deck shorts and white tube socks. It’s impossible to imagine any other British new wave singer of the MTV era dressing this way for a quick dash to the hotel ice machine, much less for a video.

abstract: Do you ever think about your ecological footprint — how much your individual actions affect the environment?
lead_paragraph: For the world to slow down or stop human-generated climate change, governments and corporations will need to enact major policy shifts. But still, each of us plays a small role in Earth’s overall health — through our everyday decisions like turning on or off the lights, buying and reusing clothing or electronics, littering and recycling, or turning up or down the air-conditioning and the heat.

headline: ‘The Washingtons,’ by Flora Fraser
abstract: A chronicle of the marriage of George and Martha Washington.
lead_paragraph: One of the great challenges of setting down the history of marginalized people is how to amass enough information to provide a clear picture of subjects who didn’t write letters themselves or only appeared in the letters of others, who didn’t enter the public realm through the legal system or gain notoriety in other ways. It’s hard to imagine two people less marginalized than George and Martha Washington, a couple at the very pinnacle of society in the nation George helped to create. Martha lived this very public life with him, garnering enormous respect.

headline: Patti Smith’s ‘M Train’
abstract: In this memoir, Smith meanders between her interior life and her life in the world, connecting dreams, reflections and memories.
lead_paragraph: Many people, especially those who came of age in the 1970s, view Patti Smith as an inimitable punk-rock poet with an edgy, unforgettable voice. But she is also a regular person. Her new memoir, “M Train,” can be seen as a plea to acknowledge her as one. Like the rest of us ordinary folk, she endures the frustrations and banalities of everyday life — keeping despair at bay with TV crime shows, cats and caffeine. She identifies unapologetically with the detectives on “The Killing” and “CSI: Miami.” I “adopt their ways,” she explains, “suffer their failures and consider their movements long after an episode ends, whether in real time or rerun.” Her cats are not cuddly and decorative but authentic. One wakes her in the morning by throwing up on the edge of her pillow. Her drug of choice is black coffee. Much of “M Train” takes place in different cafes, and the reader can map the effect of the substance on her imagination. With each sip her mind awakens and her ruminations deepen.

headline: ‘St. Marks Is Dead,’ by Ada Calhoun
abstract: St. Marks Place in New York has been home to visionaries, thrill seekers and aimless beauties for 400 years.
lead_paragraph: New York breeds mourners. If you grow up anywhere in the city, there is a good chance your childhood memories will be bundled with tangible goods and sold to the highest bidder before you reach adulthood. You won’t be invited to the memorial service — New York runs a red light past sentiment. The city grows on the frictional power of millions chasing The Now. Money is New York’s longest-­running Now, and it probably just ate your favorite sandwich shop, the apartment you first rented or your go-to record store. Mine disappeared a few weeks ago — it was on St. Marks Place and was unassuming in aspect and name: Sounds.

headline: ‘The Catskills: Its History and How It Changed America’
abstract: The handsomely illustrated “The Catskills” aims to be a general-purpose popular history of the region.
lead_paragraph: In 1824 a group of businessmen opened the Catskill Mountain House, America’s first grand resort hotel, in a spectacular but logistically challenging location at the top of a ledge about 1,500 feet above the Hudson Valley hamlet of Palenville, N.Y. Not long after, the promising young ­British-born painter Thomas Cole, sent to the environs of the Mountain House by a patron, produced “The Falls of the Kaaterskill,” a dramatized rendering of the leading natural wonder in the hotel’s vicinity. This was a big event in the cultural history of the United States. Finally, half a century after the Declaration of Independence, there was a distinctively American form of artistic expression: the depiction of pristine and forbidding wilderness.

headline: Roger Angell’s ‘This Old Man’
abstract: Now in his mid-90s, Angell has put together a collection of literary odds and ends.
lead_paragraph: The author and editor Roger Angell, who has had a long, distinguished career, is principally celebrated for his unparalleled sports writing. Angell writes about baseball the way M.F.K. Fisher did about food, as a metaphor for life’s complexities of desire, defeat, utility and beauty.

lead_paragraph: When Winston Churchill took office as prime minister of Britain in May 1940, Nazi Germany had brought Continental Europe under its domination, and it seemed as if, barring a miracle, Britain would be next. Churchill couldn’t promise a miracle, he told the House of Commons: “I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat.” He forgot to mention a possibly more potent weapon: his wife, Clementine, the subject of Sonia Purnell’s thorough and engrossing (if occasionally overdramatized) biography.

lead_paragraph: Although they take different approaches, these three books are profoundly enmeshed in words, images and meanings. While two are wide-ranging compilations by contemporary masters of commercial graphic design, the third explores the visual possibilities offered by the most rudimentary of typographical tools. As a young designer, I was taught that everything communicates, that nothing is mute. These books raised new questions for me about meaning — whether it is fundamentally local and whether it is indeed possible to cleave meaning from words.

headline: Familiar Ground
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Working the farm alongside your ancestors in Italy.
lead_paragraph: In August, I went back to Italy for a family reunion. I’m part Welsh and part Italian, but growing up I lived in Italy. My earliest memories are of the farm where we lived and of the piazza at Vernole: There were horses and carts and Lamborghinis, barking dogs, leather-faced men and women dressed in black. My father had died recently, and in keeping with Italian inheritance law, our property in Salento, right on the heel of Italy, had to be split among all the siblings. There are six of us, and it’s not often that we can all get together. Because my son, Sean, was about to go to college, I thought it would be nice to bring him along as well, an opportunity to spend some time together.

headline: ‘Snowflakes’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Poetry and walking each invite a kind of meditation. In this poem, the contemplation of snowflakes — the precise seeing of the external landscape — gives way to the landscape of the speaker’s psyche.

headline: How to Skin a Cat
abstract: Freeze the carcass until ready. Peel the skin like an orange.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Go with the grain of the hair,’’ says Anthony Eddy, a taxidermist who has worked on house cats, bobcats and mountain lions. The cleanest of the many ways to skin a cat begins with a so-called dorsal cut. Start at the bottom of the skull, and cut a straight line to the base of the tail along the spine. ‘‘Always use a sharp blade,’’ says Eddy, who prefers a carbon steel scalpel. Peel the skin back as you would an orange. Trim carefully around the paws, mouth, nose and eyes. This is obviously not work for the squeamish, but to make a lifelike remembrance of an animal means doing things that make its death inescapable.

headline: The Legend and Lore of Notre-Dame de Reims
abstract: One of France’s most regal cathedrals has survived a volatile and storied past.
lead_paragraph: The story goes that in the 13th century, when three great French cathedrals were being built — Notre-Dame de Paris, Notre-Dame de Chartres and Notre-Dame de Reims — the builders of Notre-Dame de Reims, determined to achieve primacy over the other two and perhaps employing a bit of industrial espionage, managed to make their massive edifice just a little bit more massive than the other two. headline: 1890: King William Laid in His Grave
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The last of the Orange Kings is laid in his grave in Holland in 1890.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — The Hague is teeming to-night [Dec. 4] with joyous crowds after the burial of the last of its Orange Kings, which was, in point of fact, a brilliant pageant. The population, amounting to 183,000, reached this morning to 400,000 by the influx of foreign Princes and their suites, crowds of Belgians, Germans, Luxemburgers and Dutch provincials; 25,000 visitors came from Amsterdam alone, and many spent the night in the streets, finding no lodgings. Many of the streets were decked with tricolor flags, and the balconies and windows were decorated with black hangings. Wooden stands for sightseers were erected in all the streets, in the shop fronts and even on the decks of the barges on the canals, and places were paid for at extraordinary prices. An Englishman gave 300 florins for a window. The procession formed, one mile long, and taking seventy-five minutes to pass a given point, the principal features were the muffled drums, the military bands playing Chopin’s and Handel’s funeral dirges. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 5, 1890

headline: Anchors Away (Slightly Wonkish)
abstract: A problematic analysis, with huge implications.
lead_paragraph: Last week I wrote about what in our macroeconomic models has and hasn’t worked since 2008. As I said, demand-side events have been very much what people using IS-LM would have predicted (and did). But on the supply side, not so much. For one thing, the “accelerationist” doctrine that has dominated economic discussion of inflation and unemployment for 40 years has fallen flat. If inflation had responded to the Great Recession and aftermath the way it did in previous big slumps, we would be deep in deflation by now; we aren’t.

headline: ‘Portraits: John Berger on Artists’
abstract: Now almost 90, Berger still has the deep devotion to pictures that you might associate with a first-year art ­student.
lead_paragraph: Has John Berger mellowed? Apparently not. In his new book, the passionately wayward and contentious English writer, who once shared his Booker Prize money with the Black Panther Party, recalls being ejected from the National Gallery in London. “You have insulted one of my men,” the security chief tells Berger. “You have shouted obscene words in a public institution. You will now walk in front of us to the main exit.” Berger’s crime? He refused, after a quarrel with a guard, to put his bag on his shoulder while drawing from a favorite painting, Antonello da Messina’s “Crucifixion.” Now almost 90, Berger still has the deep devotion to pictures, not to mention the reflexive anti-­authoritarianism, that you might associate with a first-year art ­student.

headline: 1940: War Prisoners to Be Sent Food
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The American Red Cross prepares food packages for prisoners of war in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American Red Cross announced today [Dec. 4] that war prisoners in European camps will receive 5,000 packages of food before the end of the year as a result of an urgent request of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva. The shipment will be the first of what is to be known as a ‘‘prisoners-of-war package service,’’ the Red Cross said. The Red Cross announced that food would be sent first because of the great need, but that later shipments would include clothing also. The food now is being purchased and will be packed by a merchandising firm for the Red Cross. The parcels will weigh eleven pounds each, will cost approximately $2.75 and will contain evaporated milk, oatmeal, cheese, sardines, oleo margarine, dried fruit, corned beef, orange juice, sugar, cigarettes and vitamized dry beverages requiring only the addition of water. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 5, 1940

And until Episode 10, the show’s creators had done a fine job of making Jones’s search for Kilgrave feel genuinely urgent, which is pretty impressive given how many times she’s caught him, lost him, then reluctantly rendezvoused with him, and back again. “AKA 1,000 Cuts” is the first episode that has an arrhythmic pace and a generally messy structure.

headline: ‘What the Eye Hears’ and ‘America Dancing’

lead_paragraph: To an extent that seems counterintuitive from the quaint, straw-hat soft shoe typically associated with it, tap-­dancing — like so much of American popular culture — owes its very essence to black people. Like the jazz it evolved alongside, tap blends the European and the African to a near-indissoluble degree, with origins only dimly reconstructable. Brian ­Sei­bert’s authoritative “What the Eye Hears” illuminates those beginnings — along with what happened afterward — as well as anyone ever will.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Cross Justice,” which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1, is James Patterson’s ninth novel to hit the adult hardcover list in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Elephant in the Room: “Cross Justice,” the latest thriller in James Patterson’s long-running Alex Cross series, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. This has been, as usual, a very good year for Patterson: “Cross Justice” is his ninth novel to hit the adult hardcover list in 2015 (seven of them written with other people, but still), and since January he has appeared on that list, or the extended version, for all but four weeks. Patterson was at the National Book Awards ceremony last month, at Cipriani Wall Street, to accept the Literarian Award for his efforts to promote reading. “I feel uncomfortable,” he told the crowd, “because, well, I am the elephant in the room, the bull in the china shop, the stranger in a strange land, the Big Mac at Cipriani.” He went on to discuss his early love of fiction — he’s partial to the terrific novels “Mr. Bridge” and “Mrs. Bridge,” by Evan S. Connell — and to praise school libraries and independent bookstores, encouraging his listeners to help those institutions if they could: “Let’s all be literarians, whatever the hell that means.” He also revealed that his debut mystery, “The Thomas Berryman Number,” had been rejected 31 times before finding a home. “I keep a list of all the editors who turned down my first novel,” he said. “Sometimes they send me books and ask for blurbs. Mostly, though, they’re dead.”

Pitchers, with their delicate arms, cannot throw constantly to shake a slump. But hitters can swing as often as they like.

headline: Resistance Is Futile
abstract: For people who have grown cynical about self-help, new books teach you how to toughen up, ignore the haters and know your league. Brace yourself.
lead_paragraph: There’s no data on this, but I’d guess that most self-help books are purchased in the depths of a bad mood. When we’re happy, we idle and play. When we’re not, we buy books that promise a fix. And when those books fail to deliver, we feel wronged. The market has responded accordingly, with a crop of new books seemingly aimed at people who have grown cynical about self-help. These books have profane titles, saucy premises and, in one case, a cover photo of the author posing nearly nude and oiled and aiming a weapon. Their tone is belligerent. Much like their intended readers, these books could be credibly described as having an attitude problem.

lead_paragraph: Would you eat a fish caught in Prospect Park? Neither would Jamie Hodari. But that doesn’t stop Mr. Hodari, 34, whose business is creating shared office spaces, from getting out there with bait and rod and letting the prospect of catching a largemouth bass transport him to another place. Mr. Hodari is a founding partner of Industrious, which has been constructing its first outpost in New York. “It’s a little ironic,” he said in late October, “because my work is devoted to saying that working at home inhibits your creativity and makes it harder to be productive. But our first New York location doesn’t open for three weeks, so I do work from home relatively frequently.” Home is an apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, where Mr. Hodari lives alone.

headline: Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyer’s Flagship Bistro, Is About to Set Sail
abstract: After 30 years, the bistro is relocating from its perch on East 16th Street in Manhattan to the other side of Union Square.
lead_paragraph: Like certain insects or figures from Greek mythology, New York eats its own. You know how it works: A restaurant moves into an underserved area, attracts attention, then a crowd, and then other restaurants and larger crowds. Before you know it, the original restaurant can no longer afford to remain in the very neighborhood it helped create. That’s exactly what happened to Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyer’s flagship bistro. After 30 years, the restaurant is relocating from its perch on East 16th Street to the other side of Union Square. In celebration of the move, Mr. Meyer created the 12 Nights of Union Square Cafe, a three-course menu for $85 available through Dec. 12.

headline: In Miami, a Trio of Minimalist Paintings
abstract: Though figurative art is having a moment, a few galleries bucked the trend and showed spare, monochromatic paintings instead.
lead_paragraph: It’s undeniable that figuration stands tall in today’s art market — bodies of all shapes and sizes are in evidence throughout the Miami art fairs and are the subject of one of the most buzzed-about pop-up exhibitions in town, “Unrealism,” at the Design District’s Moore Building, curated by the heavyweight double bill of Jeffrey Deitch and Larry Gagosian. However, as soon as a trend hits a saturation point, the window opens wide for a counterpoint. Throughout Art Basel Miami Beach, there are a number of strikingly spare paintings whose minimal, monochromatic brushstrokes bear uncanny superficial resemblances, despite originating from very different times and places. The 78-year-old Swiss painter Niele Toroni is known for applying short, squarish acrylic streaks of a prescribed size in strict patterns; he has new works on offer at a number of booths, including Alfonso Artiaco. On offer at Greene Naftali is a historical work by the recently deceased German painter Gunther Forg — who, though prolific like Toroni, is known for constant variation rather than repetition. Finally, the Paris-based South Korean artist Lee Ufan’s canvas of two blocky gray smears at Galerie Nächst St. Stephan Rosemarie Schwarzwälder is discreetly rooted in the natural origin of its materials, which combine oil with pigments of stone.

headline: Bangladesh: Bomb Explodes at Temple
abstract: A bomb was set off outside a Hindu temple in northern Bangladesh early Saturday, wounding at least six people, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A bomb was set off outside a Hindu temple in northern Bangladesh early Saturday, wounding at least six people, the police said. The bomb exploded outside the Kantajew temple in the Dinajpur District, where about 1,500 people had gathered to watch an open-air folk performance as part of a fair in the area, said Iltutmish, a police official in the district. The motive for the attack and the identity of the attackers were not clear on Saturday. The fair, which has been held in the district for years, includes secular cultural events and often has many non-Hindu attendees, Mr. Iltutmish said. The Hindu population in Bangladesh has been dwindling for decades, down to about 8 percent of the total population of the largely Muslim country in 2011. The government has denied that the Islamic State is carrying out attacks in the country, instead identifying suspects associated with the Jamaat-e-Islami, an Islamist party associated with the political opposition. No group has yet claimed responsibility for Saturday’s attack. Mohammad Ruhul Amin, the police superintendent in Dinajpur, said that at least four people had been detained for questioning in connection with the attack, but that no arrests had been made.

headline: 1915: Turkish Army Prepares for Offensive
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Turkish army grows as a German expedition against Egypt is anticipated in 1915.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — From Balkan and Turkish sources there have reached here the following indications concerning the grouping of Turkish troops in Europe and Asia. A Turkish army is being concentrated in the region of Phillipopolis, in fulfilment of Turco-Bulgarian agreements. This army is stated to number 75,000 men. Its organization, however, is slow, and its intervention cannot be regarded as imminent. Guns of 305mm. and 210mm., sent from Germany, are reported to have arrived in the Gallipoli Peninsula, where the Turks are preparing for an offensive soon. It is asserted among German officers in Constantinople that the expedition against Egypt will set out about the beginning of next month. The Turks, evidently a prey to megalomania, state that by the spring they will have an army of two million men. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 7, 1915

headline: 1940: Vichy Schools Again to Teach Concept of God
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Schools in Vichy welcome God into the classroom in 1940.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Drastically reversing the educational policy of the Third Republic, the Pétain government promulgated today [Dec. 6] the return of the idea of God to the French public-school system. Theoretically the notion of a supreme deity was officially recognized by the charter of the French educational system as laid down by Jules Ferry, founder of the modern French public-school system, but in practice it had been ignored by the great majority of French school teachers for years. But now, by a law just promulgated, Georges Ripert, Minister of Education, has decreed that ‘‘programs of morality must henceforth be taught in the elementary and secondary schools’’ beginning Jan. 1, 1941. In the elementary schools one hour a week must be devoted to the following subject: ‘‘The principal duties of the pupils toward their neighbors (family and country) and toward God.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 7, 1940

abstract: After a narrow win over Iowa in the Big Ten title game on Saturday, the Spartans were given the third spot in the four-team bracket, just ahead of the idle Sooners and just behind Clemson and Alabama.
lead_paragraph: The final-four bracket that makes up the College Football Playoff was announced Sunday, with, as expected, Clemson, Alabama, Oklahoma and Michigan State as the four teams.

headline: Marco Rubio, Switching Focus, Aims to Halt Ted Cruz’s Momentum
abstract: In interviews, speeches and in stealthier ways, Mr. Rubio has abruptly changed the course of his campaign to zero in on Mr. Cruz and reverse his gains among conservative voters.
lead_paragraph: VAN HORNE, Iowa — For months, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida ran an above-the-fray presidential race, high-mindedly dismissing his Republican rivals’ attacks and promising a campaign his family could be proud of long after 2016.

headline: Brooklyn Man Fatally Stabbed Girlfriend as Police Were on Their Way, Officials Say
abstract: The police said officers found a chilling scene as the suspect, who is facing attempted murder charges in another case, tried to flee wearing blood-soaked clothes and plastic bags on his hands.
lead_paragraph: A man facing charges of attempted murder in an April shooting stabbed his girlfriend to death on Saturday afternoon in his basement apartment in Brooklyn as police officers were en route to the home, the police said on Sunday.

abstract: President Obama is expected to detail anti-extremism measures the country is taking and to urge Americans to “not give in to fear” on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his address to the nation on Sunday night, President Obama will most likely urge Americans to “not give in to fear,” detail measures the country is already taking to combat extremism and ask Congress to explore new ones, Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said on Sunday.

headline: ‘Star Wars’: A 6-Year-Old Fan Sees the Big Picture and Awakens
abstract: A writer endeavors to find a space big enough to watch the first installment of the series with his son — as his own father shared it with him in 1977.

headline: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Is Free of Cancer
abstract: Mr. Carter, 91, who announced in August that he had metastatic melanoma, said a recent MRI brain scan did not show any cancerous areas.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter, who has been undergoing treatment for cancer that was removed from his liver but had spread to his brain, said on Sunday that he was free of the disease.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton said on Sunday that the Islamic State had become “the most effective recruiter in the world” and that the only solution was to engage American technology companies in blocking or taking down militant websites, videos and encrypted communications.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most interesting political meeting this week may be the one between Valerie Jarrett, the closest confidante of President Obama, and Mark Holden, the general counsel for Koch Industries, the conglomerate owned by the anti-Obama Koch brothers.

headline: Let the U.S. Treasury Rescue Puerto Rico
abstract: The territory flounders in its debts while Congress fails to allow bankruptcy. It’s time for the Obama administration to get involved.
lead_paragraph: Stanford, Calif. — Last week, Puerto Rico eked out a major round of payments on its enormous debt — surely the last one that the island can afford to pay in full. The territory’s debt crisis reached a boiling point last summer and is beginning to overflow. By the new year, Puerto Rico will most likely be unable to meet payroll for basic services on the island.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the cameras blinked on for Sunday night’s address on the San Bernardino, Calif., shootings and the threat from the Islamic State, President Obama delivered it from the Oval Office, a place for speechmaking that he had largely shunned during his presidency.

headline: Giants Gamble, and Jets Cash In
abstract: Coach Tom Coughlin’s decision to go for it on fourth-and-2, rather than try a short field goal for a 13-point lead, backfired, and the Jets went on to win in overtime and bolster their playoff hopes.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Leading the Jets by 10 points in the fourth quarter Sunday, the Giants marched authoritatively down the field, keeping the football for more than 11 minutes. The Jets’ defense was in disarray, having committed two penalties on third-down plays and another on a punt to prolong the Giants’ drive.

headline: Review: Behzod Abduraimov, at People’s Symphony, Gives Each Note Its Due
abstract: In demeanor and musicianship alike, Mr. Abduraimov is no-nonsense, yet never nondescript.
lead_paragraph: The wave of young pianists breaking onto the scene has quickly become a tsunami. This autumn, both Daniil Trifonov and Benjamin Grosvenor have been in New York. Igor Levit is about to take over the Park Avenue Armory, with a little help from Marina Abramovic. In the spring, Yuja Wang and Khatia Buniatishvili will make prominent concerto appearances. Not one of them has turned 30.

headline: Review: In Anneke Hansen’s ‘2hymn vb,’ a Billowing Gown as Star
abstract: Introducing this new work at the Irondale Center, the choreographer donned a dress that nearly spanned the room.
lead_paragraph: Clothes make the man, people say, and as Martha Graham understood, a big dress can make a big impression. The choreographer Anneke Hansen knows this, too, and at the end of her new work, “2hymn vb,” which had its debut last week in the ballroom-like expanse of the Irondale Center in Brooklyn, the dress she slipped into was nearly large enough to span the room.

headline: Review: ‘Die Fledermaus’ in Full, a First Under the Baton of James Levine
abstract: Mr. Levine had never led a complete three-act performance of Johann Strauss Jr.’s breezy operetta until Friday at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: One would think that by this point in his career there are not many standard-repertory operas that James Levine has not conducted. But he had never led a complete three-act performance of Johann Strauss Jr.’s “Die Fledermaus” until Friday night, when Jeremy Sams’s 2013 staging returned to the Metropolitan Opera. (He had conducted the festive second act in special gala programs.) Mr. Levine drew a lithe and stylish account of the work from the responsive Met orchestra, an appealing cast and the dependable house chorus.

headline: Review: Sasha Waltz’s ‘Continu,’ Dances of Contrasting Moods
abstract: The German choreographer’s two-part production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music transformed the Howard Gilman Opera House from dark to light.
lead_paragraph: With 21 dancers in tow, the German choreographer Sasha Waltz whirled into the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday to transform the Howard Gilman Opera House from dark to light. It was no quick switch: her two-part “Continu” rambled on — especially the dark half, which clocked in at around 90 minutes. Then, strangely, the second half, at 30 minutes, seemed longer. (Why does that happen?)

headline: Justice Officials to Investigate Chicago Police Department After Laquan McDonald Case
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The department has had longstanding concerns about the Chicago police, but the current inquiry revolves around the scant details that were given after the shooting of the 17-year-old in 2014.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Justice Department will begin a far-ranging investigation into the patterns and practices of the Chicago Police Department, part of the continuing fallout over a video released last month showing the police shooting of Laquan McDonald, Attorney General Loretta Lynch announced Monday.

headline: Review: With ‘Neon Joe: Werewolf Hunter,’ Adult Swim Aims a Silver Bullet
abstract: Jon Glaser both created and stars in the five-part mini-series about a man whose mission in life is to hunt werewolves.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a maker of television series and want to raise awareness about North America’s severe werewolf infestation, the later your show is on, the better. Humans become more vulnerable to werewolf attacks as any given night goes along, because they get drunker, sleepier or just generally less attentive. A prime-time series like MTV’s “Teen Wolf” or Syfy’s “Bitten” is swell, but what you really want is for your werewolf show to be on at midnight.

headline: Review: The Tallis Scholars, Hovering in a Meditative Sphere
abstract: The group’s concert at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin united sacred works by Tudor-era composers with those of the equally contemplative Arvo Pärt.
lead_paragraph: Subtlety may not be the word that springs to mind when you think of Christmas concerts. But if you listened cold to the Tallis Scholars’ captivating program at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin on Saturday evening, unaware of the title, “Christmas Across Centuries,” you might have missed the theme.

headline: Review: Alvin Ailey’s ‘Awakening’ Projects a Sense of Fight-or-Flight
abstract: The premiere of Robert Battle’s new work had tempestuous passages but left some questions unanswered.
lead_paragraph: Robert Battle has joked that dancing his work is like “doing battle”: You need to be quick and tough. Combat comes to mind while watching his new piece for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, “Awakening,” which had its premiere on Friday at City Center, and not just because of John Mackey’s portentous score, music that wouldn’t be out of place in an action movie.

headline: Review: ‘Here and There,’ a Renunciation of a Sect, Tinged With Love
abstract: Chaya Deitsch’s story underlines how no two memoirs about leaving a Hasidic sect are alike, given the differences in the circumstances and the individuals.
lead_paragraph: When Chaya Deitsch was a little girl, she wandered into her parents’ bedroom and found her mother anxiously running a comb through her sheitel, the false hair worn by married Orthodox Jewish women. “Does this look too wiggy?” she asked her daughter. “I shook my head no, even though I thought that all of her wigs looked pretty fake,” Ms. Deitsch writes in “Here and There: Leaving Hasidism, Keeping my Family.”

headline: In a Red-Hot Art Market, the Collector Martin Margulies Stays Cool
abstract: Mr. Margulies, one of several notable private collectors in South Florida, has been described as living and breathing art.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — To escape the crush of the Art Basel art fair, which ended Sunday, and visit Martin Z. Margulies at his voluminous warehouse and exhibition space for art in the Wynwood Arts District is to realize that this collector was there before it all began. Before his Twomblys were trading for more than $70 million at auction. Before the Arte Povera pieces he started buying years ago became chic. Before the market got red-hot and art became an asset class.

headline: ‘The Boy in the Bubble’ Moved a World He Couldn’t Touch
abstract: The life and death of David Phillip Vetter, born in 1971 without a functioning immune system, contributed to medical advances that give hope to the once-hopeless.
lead_paragraph: The epitaph on David Phillip Vetter’s gravestone observes correctly that “he never touched the world.” How could he have? From a few seconds after his birth until two weeks before his death at age 12, David lived life entirely in one plastic bubble or another. Touching the world would have killed him in fairly short order. Even his two weeks outside a plastic cocoon were spent in a hospital trying, futilely, to stave off the inevitable.

headline: Review: Tara Erraught, Out of the Frying Pan and Into a Tranquil Recital
abstract: At Weill Recital Hall, in a set that also inclued Delius and Roger Quilter, the mezzo-soprano displayed the grace that has made her increasingly prominent.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2014, the Irish mezzo-soprano Tara Erraught got what every young singer wants — international attention — but probably not for the reason she would have chosen. Appearing at the Glyndebourne Festival in England as Octavian in Strauss’s “Der Rosenkavalier,” she faced a flood of catty criticism about her weight  that might better have been directed at the designer of her unflattering costumes.

headline: Chinese Businessman Linked to Corruption Scandals Dies in Prison, Reports Say
abstract: Xu Ming, 44, once the eighth-richest person in China, died of a heart attack, according to news reports, less than a year before his expected release.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A 44-year-old businessman who became one of China’s wealthiest people as he forged ties with some of the Communist Party’s top leaders before suddenly falling out of favor has died in prison.

headline: Review: In ‘Quantum Joy,’ Observing the Unreliable Nature of Reality
abstract: Victor Morales uses his programming skills to create virtual worlds that ostensibly illustrate concepts in physics like uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: A contested theory in quantum mechanics is that of the observer effect, how the very act of surveying a particular system might change its state. So how does each Dixon Place audience alter “Quantum Joy,” Victor Morales’s cheerful and unfocused meditation on the unreliable nature of reality?

headline: Salaries of Private College Presidents Continue to Rise, Chronicle Survey Finds
abstract: In all, 32 presidents received $1 million or more in compensation in 2013, the latest figures available, according to a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education.
lead_paragraph: Despite pressure on institutions of higher learning to hold down costs, the compensation of private college presidents continues to climb, up 5.6 percent between 2012 and 2013 to a median of $436,000, according to an annual survey.

headline: Jameis Winston Helps Buccaneers Run Past Falcons

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When the Tampa Bay Buccaneers made the Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Jameis Winston the first overall pick in this year’s N.F.L. draft, they bet that he would ignite a franchise that had not had a winning record in five seasons.

headline: X Marks the Spot That Makes Online Ads So Maddening

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Claims a Rare Victory: A Legislative Majority
abstract: For the first time in years, government opponents have won most of the seats in the National Assembly, handing a setback to President Nicolás Maduro.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Government opponents surged to a rare victory here on Sunday in key congressional elections framed by the country’s deep economic crisis, claiming a legislative majority for the first time in years and handing a significant setback to the heirs of former President Hugo Chávez and his socialist-inspired movement.

headline: How to Make Choosing the Right School Easier
abstract: Charter schools claim better performance than public schools, but conflicting data and unequal enrollment make it impossible for parents to decide.
lead_paragraph: ARE the student achievement scores at charter schools too good to be true? Every year, urban school districts across the country release test scores showing dismal student proficiency in math and reading, especially for students in poverty. At the same time, parents in those same cities often hear claims by many charter schools that their students score two or three times higher than their district school counterparts. Are these results accurate?

headline: A Silent Daughter, Reunited With Her Father, Learns to Speak 3 Languages

lead_paragraph: When Daysi Perdomo came to the United States at 7, she could barely speak, her delayed speech owing to a hearing impairment. More than two years later, she can communicate in three languages.

headline: Cam Newton Helps Panthers Remain Undefeated

headline: A Golfer Learns to Carry On While Coping With a Sleep Disorder
abstract: Nicole Jeray’s life has been anything but typical since 1996, when she was found to have narcolepsy. But she has persisted since her 1994 rookie season on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

Like the best episodes of “In Treatment,” it was intelligent, fairly engrossing — within the limits of Noah’s worldview — and a showcase for two fine actors, Dominic West and a guest star, Cynthia Nixon. It makes sense — Hagai Levi was a creator of both shows, and Sarah Treem (with whom he created “The Affair”) and Anya Epstein, who wrote the episode, were both writers and producers on “In Treatment.”

headline: Australia’s Feral Cats Most Likely European
abstract: The nation is home to more than 20 million wild cats, which have driven at least 27 native species to extinction.
lead_paragraph: Australia is home to an estimated 20 million feral cats, which prey on more than 100 of the country’s native species and have helped drive at least 27 species to extinction. Government officials recently sparked an international outcry after announcing plans to cull at least two million of the cats. But where did they come from in the first place? One theory held that the cats arrived with European explorers in the late 18th century, while another suggested that the cats came much earlier, around 1650, with Malaysian fishermen. According to a study in the journal BMC Evolutionary Biology, genetic testing of the cats indicates that they are probably descended from those brought by European settlers in the 19th century.
