headline: ‘The Occupation Trilogy’ and More, by Patrick Modiano
abstract: The Nobel Prize winner Modiano’s novels often return to occupied France.
lead_paragraph: I will not resist the temptation to read in “Pedigree” — Patrick Modiano’s 2005 memoir, newly translated in the wake of his 2014 Nobel Prize — the stuff of everything else he has ever written. Modiano has encouraged such conflation, for one thing, in interviews and essays and the like. But this on its own would be insufficient justification. Fiction or nonfiction — or, more accurately, something in between — Modiano’s more than 25 published works form a constellation of intersecting narratives that challenge any readerly desire for clarity or closure. The open-ended dialogue Modiano sustains among all of his writings frames the sketches and unsure rememberings that make up this autobiographical snapshot. Terse, yet somehow infinitely generous, “Pedigree” both enacts and accounts for Modiano’s fraught relationship with memory and the past — his own and those of his country. It outlines the stakes of his literary practice and reveals the specific sufferings this practice entails.

headline: Marilynne Robinson’s ‘The Givenness of Things’
abstract: Marilynne Robinson looks at America’s Christian beliefs in the Age of Information.
lead_paragraph: A sense of wonder pervades the powerful essays in “The Givenness of Things,” Marilynne Robinson’s new collection. “Existence is remarkable, actually incredible,” Robinson exclaims; even materiality is “profoundly amazing, uncanny.” Yet unlike physics, which has a strong sense of the “givenness” Robinson refers to in her title, neo-Darwinian positivism rejects anything — the self, the soul or God — that cannot be explained empirically. Robinson defines the “given” as something “that presents itself, reveals itself, always partially and circumstantially, accessible to only tentative apprehension, which means that it is always newly meaningful.” Calvin insisted that divine wisdom was one such “given,” perceived only “within radical limits.” Robinson does not say so, but here Calvin was deeply in tune with the great sages of the past, who all maintained that the transcendence we call God, Brahman, Nirvana or Dao must always ultimately elude us.

headline: A Whale Sculpture in Paris Aims to Help Save Some Species

lead_paragraph: PARIS — A life-size installation of a giant blue whale has been erected on the Left Bank of the Seine, intended as a reminder to negotiators at the international climate conference here that the fate of threatened species is also in their hands.

headline: A Bookshop Where Everything Is Recommended
abstract: One Grand, a new store in Narrowsburg, N.Y., sells titles suggested by a slew of famous names — including Tilda Swinton and Edmund White.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday afternoon, the journalist and editor Aaron Hicklin was standing among some still-empty shelves in his newly completed bookstore, One Grand, in a former mercantile building in the town of Narrowsburg, New York. In less than one week, he would open the doors to the shop, but at the moment he was still fretfully awaiting the final shipments of his stock. “I’ll be honest, I am really surprised by how many books you need to fill a space,” Hicklin said. “I have about a thousand in here, but you’d never know it. I’ve got to fill these damn shelves!”

headline: The Best TV Shows of 2015

lead_paragraph: The television critics of The New York Times — James Poniewozik, Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger — share their picks for the best shows of the year.

headline: Letters From the Pacific, From Pearl Harbor to Okinawa
keywords: ['Letters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Hundreds of letters from an Army private named Harold Grove Moss, whose tour of duty spanned Pearl Harbor to the surrender of Japan, have been transcribed and posted online by his daughter.
lead_paragraph: On December 2, 1941, an Army private named Harold Grove Moss was a week away from finishing his Morse Code training to become a radio operator. He was stationed at Camp Roberts in California. “Something seemingly a little unusual happened yesterday and that was all the Japanese boys were taken out of our battery,” he wrote that day in a letter to his parents in Minatare, Neb. But he didn’t dwell on it; he also mentioned that a homemade cake they sent “wasn’t broken a bit,” and ended with a modest Christmas list, including “a camera” and a “pair of brown civilian shoes (no two tone).” Five days later, as news of the attack on Pearl Harbor was filtering through the ranks, he wrote again.

headline: In Search of American Fascism
abstract: Why Trumpism and other American populisms can tend toward fascism without arriving at it.
lead_paragraph: Last week I used my inaugural 2016 Campaign Stops column to weigh in on the “is Donald Trump a fascist” debate, and came around to the conclusion that he is more fascistic, at least, than most of the populist candidates (Wallace, Perot, Buchanan) to whom he’s reasonably been compared. But with the strong showings yesterday in France for a party with historical roots in actual, genuine-article fascism, it seems worth digging a little bit into the ways in which Trump doesn’t deserve the fascist label, and what they say about the usefulness of the term in the American context.

lead_paragraph: Following the opening of its London outpost earlier this year, the cult New York chocolate company Mast Brothers plans to set up shop in downtown L.A.’s Arts District in the spring. And with it will come a whole new set of flavors: “We shouldn’t just ship out chocolate from Brooklyn,” the Williamsburg-based company’s co-founder Rick Mast says. “California should make chocolate for Californians.” In the meantime, though, Mast Brothers has made an exception to fly in bars from Brooklyn for a 10-week pop-up shop.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 11: The Blues
abstract: We learn a little more about Jessica and Trish’s backstory.
lead_paragraph: This episode feels like a long, slow anticlimax after the last one’s galvanizing conclusion. Hope Schlottman’s suicide makes Jessica Jones see red: Jones promises to avenge Hope’s death by murdering Kilgrave. That promise weighs on Jones throughout Episode 11, but much of that time is devoted to reassuring viewers that Jones isn’t really a killer. Through unmemorable flashbacks to Trish and Jones’s childhood, and a drawn-out confrontation with a comically unhinged Will Simpson, the episode writers Scott Reynolds and Liz Friedman hold viewers’ hands, and instantly resolve a conflict that was just introduced.

headline: ‘Chi-Raq’ and the Myth of Chicago Gang Wars
abstract: What Spike Lee misunderstands about the city's street violence, and why it matters.
lead_paragraph: Toward the beginning of Spike Lee’s new film, “Chi-Raq,” a gun battle erupts in a hip-hop club. It’s the latest salvo in an ongoing war between two fictional Chicago gangs: the Spartans, clad in purple, and the Trojans, in orange. (Lee’s film is a sly retelling of Aristophanes’ “Lysistrata,” the Greek comedy whose heroine tries to end the Peloponnesian War by organizing women to withhold sex from their husbands.) In “Chi-Raq,” the leader of the Trojans is a cackling, piratical figure named Cyclops, bejeweled eye patch and all. Pitted against him is the rapper known as Chi-Raq, the boss of the Spartans. But as the conflict escalates, we never find out why the two gangs are warring — this, it seems, is simply what Chicago gang members do.

Modeling, she notes, is impermanent, “but I plan to be designing and creating for a long time.”

abstract: At this year’s fair, works on view at standout galleries were literally eye-catching, incorporating neon, candy-colored hues and reflective surfaces.
lead_paragraph: With 267 international galleries gathered under one roof, art fairs like Art Basel Miami Beach have the potential both to establish new market obsessions and to perpetuate them. Walking the aisles of the convention center this year, several trend-worthy patterns emerged, but the most prevalent among them might have been the flashes of neon that seemed to be around each turn — maybe a sly nod to Miami’s native aesthetic.

headline: Review: ‘This Old Man’ Is Roger Angell’s Follow-Up to an Earlier Memoir
abstract: Mr. Angell, now 95, uses a collection of essays, letters and other writings to recount his life and journalism career.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 95, the New Yorker writer and editor Roger Angell has seen an awful lot of changes in New York City. Horses have vanished from the city streets — unless you count the weary carriage horses transporting tourists around Central Park. Gotham’s old phone exchanges (BUtterfield 8, BRyant 9) long ago gave way to colorless seven-digit numbers and, more recently, to more unwieldy 11-digit ones. Old Yankee Stadium is gone, and gone, too, is its “Voice of God,” Bob Sheppard; and an “original sweetie-pie,” Don Zimmer, whose “bald cannonball head and stumpy bod and jack-o’-lantern grin” and “wisdom accrued from tens of thousands of innings” made fans feel connected to baseball’s storied and swiftly receding past.

headline: Review: ‘The Goodbye Studies’ Explores the Idea of the Crowd

Throughout his career, the veteran choreographer Tere O’Connor has been waging a vehement battle against assigning meaning to dance. But in “The Goodbye Studies,” he veers toward it — on his own terms.

headline: Iran: Deadly Swine Flu Outbreak Is Likely to Spread, Official Warns
abstract: At least 33 people have died from a swine flu virus outbreak in two provinces of southwestern Iran in the past three weeks.
lead_paragraph: At least 33 people have died from a swine flu virus outbreak in two provinces of southwestern Iran in the past three weeks, the country’s deputy health minister, Ali-Akbar Sayyari, said Monday. Mr. Sayyari also said the virus, known as H1N1, was likely to spread to other areas, including Tehran, the capital and Iran’s largest city with about 8.3 million people. Mr. Sayyari’s remarks, reported by the official Islamic Republic News Agency, did not explain the precise origin of the outbreak or how the Iranian authorities intended to combat it. Swine flu is named for a virus that infects pigs, but the H1N1 strain, which first emerged in 2009, spreads via human-to-human contact and escalated into a global pandemic before it was contained after a year. The virus is now considered a human seasonal flu virus, according to the Department of Health and Human Services in the United States, and can be prevented with a vaccine.

headline: Italy: Iraqi With Terrorism Ties Is Arrested in Illegal Migration Case
abstract: The police identified the man as Majid Muhamad, 45, who served 10 years in an Italian prison on terrorism charges, and who was released a year ago.
lead_paragraph: The Italian police arrested an Iraqi man with extremist ties on Monday who they suspect helped foreigners pass illegally through the southeastern port city of Bari. The police identified the man as Majid Muhamad, 45, who served 10 years in an Italian prison on terrorism charges, and who was released a year ago. “He was a known terrorist” who had been affiliated with Ansar al-Islam, a radical group often linked to Al Qaeda, said Michele De Tullio, an official with the police’s special operations division in Bari. The investigation began in February, when Mr. Muhamad was found to be in contact with Ayachi Bassam, an imam in the Brussels district of Molenbeek, who was arrested — and later convicted — on terrorism charges in Bari. Mr. Bassam was released on appeal. Mr. De Tullio said that since Mr. Muhamad’s release, he had “renewed his contacts to extremist affiliates.”

headline: When the ‘Narrative’ Becomes the Story

abstract: In this never-ending election season, politicians and pundits return again and again to repetitive, contrived dramas.
lead_paragraph: When did a plain story become a perpetual narrative? It used to be that after something happened, our leaders, or would-be leaders, would simply debate whatever occurred. It was not always elegant or polite. But the exercise was at least direct. Politicians would unfurl their platforms and attacks and (if they wanted to get all lofty about it) their ‘‘visions.’’ The media would cover it, and then we could all go on with our lives without having to endure an endless belch of rapid reactions and step-back analyses.

headline: Trudeau’s Canada, Again
abstract: With support from President Obama and the legacy of his father on his side, Justin Trudeau sets out to redefine what it means to be Canadian.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Nov. 10, six days after Justin Trudeau, leader of the Liberal Party, was sworn in as prime minister of Canada, I was shown into his office on the third floor of the Parliament building in Ottawa. A dark oak-paneled room, it contained a jumble of outsize furniture chosen by the previous occupant, Stephen Harper, whose Conservative Party was in power for a decade. The office had the air of a recently abandoned bunker — shelves bare, curtains drawn, personal effects hastily removed. Trudeau’s father, Pierre, occupied the same office for 16 years during the 1960s, ’70s and ’80s, and the new prime minister would shortly install his father’s old desk, a symbol of restoration but also an emphatic rejection of his predecessor. The squat, bulldoglike bureau left by the departing prime minister, Trudeau implied, was a reflection of Harper’s autocratic manner.

headline: The Trendiest Tofu
abstract: Beloved by chefs like Brooks Headley, of Superiority Burger fame, and even Chipotle, Hodo Soy’s product line finally comes to the East Coast.

My attraction to it was bewildering: I’ve never been a vegetarian and, up until then, fell somewhere between indifferent and contemptuous on the spectrum of tofu appreciation. Sold locally at places like Bi-Rite Market, a gourmet paradise, the packaged proteins were made by Hodo Soy at its then-two-year-old beanery across the bridge in Oakland. Here was tofu that didn’t try to be something it wasn’t — unlike tofurkey or seitan — and was both texturally rewarding and delicious. Back home in Manhattan, I craved it.

headline: 270 Kinds of Birds, in One Gigantic Life-Sized Mural
abstract: Jane Kim’s recently completed work for the Cornell Lab of Ornithology spans 70 by 40 feet and depicts every modern bird family (and some dinosaurs, too).
lead_paragraph: Last night, Jane Kim revealed a 2,800-square-foot painted mural depicting 375 million years of avian evolution for the 100th anniversary of Cornell University’s Lab of Ornithology. It’s quite a departure from the average scientific-illustration commission. “If it were a 8.5-by-11 illustration in a magazine, it would have turned into something very different than when you have a 70-by-40-foot wall and you have the opportunity to show things to scale,” she says. That’s right: 270 species (including representatives from each of the 243 modern bird families, plus 27 dinosaurs and pre-prehistoric beasts) are all depicted at actual size, spanning from the 30-foot Yutyrannus and a nine-foot ostrich to the broadbill and manakin that are mere inches long. “For me, the size is what is really impactful, having a gigantic world map, and being able to put all these birds that you don’t get to see together, life-sized, next to each other — it’s really remarkable,” she says.

headline: ‘The Japanese Lover,’ by Isabel Allende
abstract: Allende’s latest centers on a secret interracial romance.
lead_paragraph: Isabel Allende has built her reputation on romantic love. But her new fairy tale of a novel, “The Japanese Lover,” doesn’t allow love to get in the way of comfort. As in all of Allende’s fiction, we find a large, colorful cast of characters, this time swirling around the octogenarian Alma Belasco, happily if peculiarly ensconced in Lark House, a retirement home in San Francisco. Foremost is Irina Bazili, the young Moldovan immigrant whose repressed “terrors” of adolescence form a drumbeat of foreshadowing through the three years of her service to Alma. But as the story lurches back to the late 1930s and then to the highlights between, we also meet Alma’s Jewish family in pre-World War II Europe; the San Francisco relatives who adopt her; the entire family of her Japanese lover, Ichimei Fukuda; and a host of other lovers, care givers, evildoers and saints. No character is so minor as to lack a back story. At the same time, no character, including Alma and Irina, manages to fill in his or her outlines and command our undivided attention.

headline: Antony Beevor’s ‘Ardennes 1944’
abstract: A new account of the Battle of the Bulge forces a reassessment of familiar military leaders.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas Eve 1944, some 30 soldiers in gray SS uniforms entered the village of Bande in Belgium, following in the wake of the German units that had punched a huge hole in Allied lines. They were, in a way, the first “European” security force — French, Belgian and Dutch fascists led by a Swiss, all in the service of the Sicherheitsdienst (SD), the secret service of the SS. They gathered all of the Belgian males of military age and, with the exception of one who escaped, beat them and shot each one in the back of the head. The SD troopers were not alone: Particularly (but not exclusively) in the elite Waffen-SS units, it was common to plunder, rape and murder the hapless villagers of the Ardennes, who had thought themselves liberated, their war over.

headline: ‘Hubris: The Tragedy of War in the Twentieth Century,’ by Alistair Horne

lead_paragraph: In 1984, the eminent American historian Barbara W. Tuchman, known for narrative masterpieces like “The Guns of August” and “The Proud Tower,” published a disjointed volume called “The March of Folly.” In it, she attempted to generalize about various mistakes made over the centuries, beginning with the Trojans opening their city walls to a wooden Greek horse, continuing on to the Renaissance popes who failed to stem the abuses leading to the Reformation and the British leaders who failed to prevent or stop an American revolt, before concluding with the mishandling of the Vietnam War — which for obvious reasons of proximity clearly was the mistake closest to her heart.

headline: Serious Play
abstract: Instagram — free, chaotic and immediate — has become a place to watch great photographers work out their obsessions.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Shore was 24 in 1972 when he took his first photographic road trip across the United States. Using color film and a 35-millimeter Rollei, he shot a bewildering variety of subjects: roads, homes, gas stations, fluorescent bulbs, pay phones, hotel beds, cars and televisions. He took pictures of friends and strangers, meals and toilets, framed paintings on walls, fridges left open, shop fronts after hours: anything, it seemed, at which the camera could be pointed. The body of work he made over the next two years, eventually exhibited and published as ‘‘American Surfaces,’’ feels oddly familiar now. With its flatness and indiscriminate subject matter, it looks just like the stuff people put on Instagram. But for all their casual affect, Shore’s images are sophisticated, supported by an instinct for pictorial structure. Along with William Eggleston, he was a pioneer of an American visual demotic, long before anyone could have dreamed of social media.

headline: The Deported
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Uprooted from his life and family in the United States, a Honduran deportee returns to the country that he tried so hard to escape.
lead_paragraph: Kelvin Villanueva was almost home one night last June when a policeman stopped him for a broken taillight. From his truck, he could see his longtime girlfriend, Suelen Bueno, waiting for him behind the glass door of their apartment. She often did that when he worked late. Villanueva supervised a small team of Hondurans — like him, undocumented migrants — who did finish carpentry on construction projects throughout Kansas City. It was normal for them to put in 12-to-14-hour days. During his 15 years in the United States, he had never been pulled over. Still, Bueno worried. The threat of deportation did not subside with time. You just had more to lose.

headline: The Original Nike Windbreaker Gets a High-Fashion Update

lead_paragraph: Sneakerheads, stand down — Nike will spend 2016, an Olympics year, celebrating the jacket that put it on the apparel map at the 1980 U.S. Olympic trials. Both the Japanese label Sacai and the Italian sportswear brand Stone Island updated the Windrunner in honor of the occasion: Sacai’s creative director, and frequent Nike collaborator, Chitose Abe rendered the hood and body in an irreverent faux-fur; Stone Island brought its material and dyeing expertise to the silhouette with water- and wind-resistant Mussola Gommata and Nylon Metal fabrics. The two resulting styles “couldn’t be more different,” says NikeLab senior design director Jarrett Reynolds. The sportswear staple “continues to inspire, not only those who wear it, but those who use it as a canvas for their own creation.”

headline: 1940: Murillo Canvas Is Sent to Spain
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Pétain government gives a painting by Murillo to Spain in 1940.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — The famous seventeenth century painting ‘‘The Immaculate Conception,’’ by Murillo, which used to attract the immediate attention of all who visited the Grand Gallery of the Louvre Museum at Paris by the angelic expression on the face of the central figure and the delicate blue tint of the draperies, has been handed over to Spain by the Pétain government. It will henceforth adorn the walls of the Prado Museum in Madrid. The loss of this celebrated masterpiece was first communicated to the French people today [Dec. 9] in the form of a Madrid dispatch of two paragraphs published at the bottom of a page in ‘‘Le Temps.’’ It stated merely that Francois Pietri, the French Ambassador at Madrid, had gone to the station there to meet the train bringing the picture to its new home. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 10, 1940

headline: Review: Matthew Welch Offers Ethereal Chamber Music at the Stone

Yet much of the resulting chamber music is exquisitely ethereal, made up of delicate, transparent textures that hum with expressive tension. If Mr. Welch were a chef, he’d be the kind who pushes the boundaries of molecular gastronomy, transforming earthy ingredients into translucent beads of pure flavor.

headline: Art as Social Critique — With a Little Help From the Rolling Stones and Katy Perry
abstract: The mixed-media works in Deborah Kass’s new show “No Kidding” are both cynical and droll, and draw from over 100 years of pop culture.
lead_paragraph: When you walk into “No Kidding,” the artist Deborah Kass’s exhibition opening tonight at Paul Kasmin Gallery, be prepared for a strange sensation: you can almost hear Kass’s new mixed-media paintings in addition to seeing them. “The thing about music is that it’s so democratic, and art isn’t,” Kass said when T visited her studio last month. Throughout the show, the artist alludes to popular song lyrics from a wide swath of eras, from the 1895 waltz “The Band Played On” to Fats Waller’s 1929 “(What Did I Do to Be So) Black and Blue” to Katy Perry’s 2010 “Teenage Dream.” The references are diverse, but taken as a whole, their message is clear: a deep-seated, and deeply droll, cynicism about the present political and artistic climate, and about our capacity to fiddle while Rome burns. Other pieces in the show ironically deploy phrases like “GOOD TIMES” and, in several three-panel works, “WHO BLUE WHO,” to much the same effect.

He was sentenced to life in prison for his role in a gun and grenade attack on the Islamic College in Hebron, in which three Palestinian students were killed, but his sentence was commuted and he was released after about seven years. Earlier on Wednesday, a Palestinian stabbed and wounded two Israelis in the West Bank city of Hebron, the Israeli authorities said. An Israeli security guard fatally shot the assailant at the scene.

headline: Report Traces Ebola’s Spread in Liberia
abstract: The height of the epidemic in Liberia can be traced back to a single case of the disease probably introduced from Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: Ebola viruses that sickened many people during the height of the epidemic in Liberia can be traced back to a single case of the disease probably introduced from Sierra Leone, according to a report published Wednesday in the journal Cell Host and Microbe. “The data are consistent with the vast majority of cases in Liberia coming from a single event,” said Jason T. Ladner of the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute for Infectious Diseases. The virus then spread from Liberia back into Guinea, where the current epidemic was first identified. Scientists analyzed genomic sequences from 140 blood samples, nearly 2 percent of all reported cases in Liberia, collected over 11 months, after a smaller outbreak had been controlled. Liberia had no new Ebola cases last week, and a recent cluster was most likely linked to a rare case of transmission from a survivor, officials said Wednesday.

abstract: This satirical novel about Ireland’s financial crisis casts an investment banker as an Everyman.
lead_paragraph: Paul Murray’s satirical novel of the Irish banking crisis, “The Mark and the Void,” takes place primarily at the International Financial Services Center, a section of Dublin that functions as a tax haven for multinational corporations, a place where billions in assets hide behind brass nameplates in the Transaction House and shadow banks operate hidden from the prying eyes of regulators. It’s anonymous by design. As one of Murray’s characters explains: “We’re in the middle of Dublin, where Joyce set ‘Ulysses.’ But it doesn’t look like Dublin. We could be in London or Frankfurt or Kuala Lumpur.”

headline: ‘The White Road,’ by Edmund de Waal
abstract: A ceramist looks to porcelain, its history in the West and its influence on his work.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine inherited a ­Bavarian coffee set from her maternal great-­grandmother, a woman who fled Europe in the late 1930s, carrying little more than the purpose-built, velvet-lined case that still holds it. That family is scattered across the globe and the way of life the coffee set embodied has vanished, but the dainty china pot and matching cups remain flawless. Porcelain is like that. We all know that the sweep of a careless elbow can shatter it into unmendable bits. But take some basic precautions and in a hundred years it will look as good as new — its colors undimmed, its whites snowy — after you and your children are dead and gone. It is fragile, and it is strong.

headline: Behind the Scenes of ‘Take Flight’
abstract: The secret of flying, explained.
lead_paragraph: Some might imagine that all the magic happens in postproduction these days, but so much of it is actually done on the set. For several of our short films, special-effects technicians strapped the actors into harnesses and worked these rigs in three-person teams, pulling them to and fro, almost like marionettes. Even from that perch, the actors had to do an incredible amount of work to complete the illusion: to convincingly look weightless or airborne, even when they were strung up somewhere in Los Angeles. I had no idea just how physically demanding the work is. It’s not easy to fly.

headline: Editor’s Letter: Take Flight With Virtual Reality
abstract: In the magazine’s new V.R. project, we send our readers up, up and away.
lead_paragraph: Movies are one of the few forms of illusion to which we regularly submit ourselves without skepticism or scorn. They transport us with visual effects, and we are happy to enjoy the journey without scrutinizing too hard how it was accomplished. Never is this more true than when the illusion is one of flight, which may be Hollywood’s most enduring and iconic form of movie magic. When Superman blazes through the sky or Mary Poppins floats away, few moviegoers stop to ask how they achieved liftoff.

headline: Tracing Diane Simpson’s Structural Evolution in Boston Exhibition

Ms. Simpson’s work, best known in and around her hometown, Chicago, is distinctive for the way it elegantly parses the components of garments like aprons, samurai armor, Amish bonnets, muffs and evening attire to create strange yet recognizable wonders of articulated form. Her materials of cardboard, fabric, metal and wood enhance the familiar formality of the work as well as the evocations of buildings and bodies and of the human mind at work.

Within pine bough-draped chalets, everything from wooden toys and hand-blown glass ornaments to gingerbread houses and farmhouse jams are on offer. And this season, the little French town will also celebrate the newly renovated and expanded Musée Unterlinden when it opens on Saturday. Located in a cloistered 13th-century Dominican convent, the museum is one of the most visited small museums in France and is best known for its Isenheim Altarpiece, which was sculpted and painted by the German artists Niclaus of Haugenau and Matthias Grünewald respectively between 1512 and 1516.

headline: Delicate, Magical Portraits of Plants’ Inner Lives
abstract: Alice Cazenave uses leaves that have been stripped of pigment as photographic negatives to create her pretty, precise photos.
lead_paragraph: Do plants have souls? With her “Honesty Pictures” series, the artist Alice Cazenave aims to find out, by capturing the delicate inner workings of leaves and stems. Inspired by her background in molecular science as well as her family history of craftspeople (her relatives have included cabinetmakers and draftswomen), Cazenave employs experimental, camera-free techniques to get at the essence of plants. She strips the leaves of pigment by washing them in chemical solutions that transform them into translucent, glassy structures, then uses them directly as negatives, placing them onto photosensitive paper and then exposing them to light. She doesn’t use lenses or screens, in an effort to create images as a “direct consequence of an interaction between light and object,” she says. This series is intended to capture a sense of “shadows peeled off the real” — and to restore a sense of wonder and mystery to a medium that has become almost universally accessible. “Much of my work comments on the growing disengagement with the natural world, and aims to re-establish a sense of magic and alchemy to photography, which I feel in recent times has been lost.”

Don’s specialty is biblical artifacts — actual stuff mentioned in the Old and New Testament — and he captivates church audiences with tales of his discoveries. lead_paragraph: As the ice caps melt, the trickle of movies about nature’s revenge may turn into a deluge. There are oceans already sloshing through “In the Heart of the Sea,” the latest from the director Ron Howard, about the shipwreck that was an inspiration for Herman Melville’s “Moby-Dick.” Epic in ambition, it spans decades and miles as it moves from Nantucket to a Pacific whale hunt that pits man (Chris Hemsworth) against Leviathan. headline: Review: The Pacifica Quartet Interprets Composers’ ‘Last Words’
abstract: This program at the 92nd Street Y featured the last string quartets written by Beethoven, Janacek and Elliott Carter.
lead_paragraph: Schubert knew he was dying when, in 1828, he wrote his final three piano sonatas. Beethoven was deaf and ill in 1826, the year before he died, when he composed his String Quartet No. 16. But Elliott Carter was still going strong when he finished his String Quartet No. 5 in 1995, at 87. He composed  dozens more pieces before he died in 2012, completing his last work just a few months before his death at 103.

headline: Vatican Says Catholics Should Not Try to Convert Jews
abstract: A new document meant to solidify the Vatican’s increasingly positive relations with Jews says members should work to fight anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Catholics should not try to convert Jews, but should work together with them to fight anti-Semitism, the Vatican said on Thursday in a far-reaching document meant to solidify its increasingly positive relations with Jews.

headline: Four Rewarding Shows in Philadelphia
abstract: Norman Lewis, Audubon, Warhol and Christopher Knowles are among the artists whose work makes now an inviting time to go.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Rarely is it a better time than now for a trip to Philadelphia, where four of the city’s major art institutions are presenting exceptionally rewarding shows, each distinctively its own thing. The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts offers a comprehensive retrospective of the career of Norman Lewis, the first such exhibition to be devoted to this African-American Modernist painter and one that invites viewers to consider Mr. Lewis’s place in the history of the country’s art. Dazzling the eyes and intriguing the mind, the Philadelphia Museum of Art presents two centuries’ worth of American still-life paintings and sculptures, from John James Audubon’s images of birds and mammals to Andy Warhol’s Brillo boxes. The Barnes Foundation has an astounding presentation of extravagantly ornamental antique works of wrought iron from a French museum, including door knockers with demonic faces and coffee grinders that look as if dreamed up by a steampunk artist. And the Institute of Contemporary Art at the University of Pennsylvania has a solo show of delightfully offbeat works by the self-taught New York artist Christopher Knowles.

headline: Review: ‘World Ballet Stars’ Puts a Spotlight on Bucharest From a Global Cast
abstract: A production in honor of the ballet of the Bucharest National Opera House featured guest artists from the New York City Ballet and the Mariinsky Ballet, among others.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the World Ballet Stars gala-style event on Wednesday at the Rose Theater, the ballerina Alina Cojocaru, who had danced in four of the 15 items on the program, made a speech that epitomized the endearing spell she casts. She scarcely spoke about herself; she was all gratitude and admiration for others. Her voice (like her dancing) expressed youthfulness, fragility, radiance, courage. It is easy to care for her, easy to want to cry because of her, easy to admire her.

headline: In ‘Robert Ryman,’ One Color With the Power of Many
abstract: Dia’s first exhibition in Chelsea in a decade is a beautifully installed, comprehensive exhibition of Mr. Ryman’s works.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 60 years, the Minimalist painter Robert Ryman has had few equals when it comes to doing more with less. White has been his primary, if not quite his only, color, the square his typical format. And yet within these seeming limitations a remarkably fecund and resonant body of work has evolved, as demonstrated by a small but comprehensive exhibition at Dia:Chelsea on West 22nd Street.

headline: Vaginal Davis’s Feminist Wall Reliefs Pledge ‘Open Revolt’
abstract: For this show, the self-described intersex artist has fashioned masklike forms from materials like nail enamel, hair spray and perfume.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to know where to begin with the self-described intersex artist Vaginal Davis, because there’s so much there. Born in Los Angeles in the 1960s, she’s a performer, writer, editor, composer and painter, and her solo show at Invisible-Exports adds sculptor to the résumé. The exhibition’s 16 wall reliefs, while modest in size, give the term multimedia a serious stretch, each piece having being made from — and I quote the exhibition’s checklist — “clay, stucco fragments, wet n wild brickhouse nail varnish, neon nail lacquer, Rival de Loop nylon nail enamel, hydrogen peroxide, glycerin, witch hazel, Pam, Aqua Net extra-strength hair spray and Jean Naté perfume.”

headline: Seth, Poet of the Ordinary, in ‘Nothing Lasts’
abstract: An exhibition at Adam Baumgold features drawings for two chapters of an autobiographical story by this Canadian comic book artist.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed comic-book artist Seth (real name, Gregory Gallant) is a poet of the ordinary and the downbeat, a nostalgic chronicler of regret, disappointment, confusion and occasional moments of happiness. This enchanting exhibition features 80 original drawings for two chapters from the autobiographical story “Nothing Lasts.” The first 40-page section appeared in the 22nd issue of “Palookaville,” a series begun by Seth in 1991 and published by Drawn & Quarterly. The second will soon appear in “Palookaville 23.”

headline: Jean Tinguely’s Kinetic Sculptures at Gladstone Gallery
abstract: Machine parts, found objects and sounds dominate the first New York show in four decades for Tinguely.
lead_paragraph: This exhibition provides a rare look at the discombobulated kinetic sculptures of the Swiss artist Jean Tinguely (1925-1991), a prominent member of the postwar European avant-garde. Tinguely’s found-object assemblages contributed vocally to his generation’s turn away from figurative sculpture. He is probably best remembered in the United States for his Dadaist “Homage to New York,” a self-destructing junk sculpture cobbled together from scrap metal and mechanical elements that he activated in the Museum of Modern Art’s sculpture garden in March 1960. Since its demise was halted by the fire department, a surviving fragment is in the museum’s collection.

headline: Hilary Harnischfeger and a Host of Forms at Rachel Uffner
abstract: Ms. Harnischfeger’s rough-edged, mongrel objects continue to strengthen, looking more alien than ever.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Harnischfeger’s mongrel objects continue to strengthen, looking more alien than ever. Elaborately handmade, they sidestep traditional painting and sculpture to conjure (and sometimes use) a host of applied art forms: ceramics, mosaics, textiles, jewelry and architectural decoration. The usual notions of skill and finish are deferred; scale is confusing, as these things are too dense for their size.

abstract: Now that Moriah Galleries, one of Manhattan’s oldest purveyors of Jewish ritual objects and art, has closed, Menorah Galleries has bought its inventory.
lead_paragraph: Moriah Galleries, one of Manhattan’s oldest purveyors of Jewish ritual objects and art, has closed after six decades and sold its inventory to one of the newest Judaica stores in New York, Menorah Galleries. In three basement rooms at the Manhattan Art & Antiques Center on Second Avenue, Menorah Galleries has set up Jewish antiques — many of them salvaged from destroyed synagogues and decimated communities — that are rarely the subject of exhibitions and sales.

headline: Review: Dan Auerbach Leads the Arcs at Terminal 5
abstract: At Terminal 5, Mr. Auerbach revisits the spiritual time period of his longtime group, the Black Keys, but with a very different spirit.
lead_paragraph: It was throwback Wednesday when the Arcs, led by Dan Auerbach, played a packed Terminal 5. Mr. Auerbach, who has been the guitarist and singer of the Black Keys since 2001, situates the Arcs somewhere near the end of the 1960s, as a kind of rock and soul revue that can knock out Motown beats, fuzz-toned boogies or slow-grooving R&B. The time frame is similar to the one Mr. Auerbach visits with the Black Keys, but the spirit is different: simultaneously, and paradoxically, more communal and more desolate.

headline: With Remarks in Affirmative Action Case, Scalia Steps Into ‘Mismatch’ Debate
keywords: ['AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Equal Educational Opportunities']
abstract: With Justice Antonin Scalia’s remarks in a case on admissions at the University of Texas, he stepped into a long debate over an academic theory.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Representative André Carson was first introduced to Islam, he was a young man watching as his Muslim neighbors escorted older women to the grocery store and scared drug dealers off their streets in Indianapolis.

headline: Divers Search for Electronics of San Bernardino Attackers

That kind of talk is standard for the practically beatified jazz saxophonist John Coltrane, one of the only musicians in history to have a church consecrated in his name. But these dancers don’t have to describe Coltrane’s music, only dance to it.

headline: Antibiotic Sales for Food Rise
abstract: Despite a major effort by the Obama administration to reduce the use of antibiotics, the amount of those drugs sold for use in animals grown for food rose again last year.
lead_paragraph: Despite a major effort by the Obama administration to reduce the use of antibiotics, the amount of those drugs sold for use in animals grown for food rose again last year. Sales to farmers and ranchers rose by 3 percent from 2013, the Food and Drug Administration said, and sales are up by 23 percent since 2009, when the agency began reporting the figures. Indiscriminate antibiotic use, in people and animals, is leading to the rise of superbugs resistant to many critical drugs. Critics say the use of antibiotics to prevent sickness in animals is too sweeping. Lance Price, a researcher at the Milken Institute School of Public Health, noted that cephalosporins, a class of drug often used to treat ear and urinary tract infections, rose 12 percent last year, which he said doctors would find troubling.

headline: How to Prepare for an Earthquake
abstract: Bolt everything down. Pack solar-powered chargers, fresh water and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Bolt heavy objects to the wall,’’ says Ross S. Stein, a geophysicist who teaches at Stanford University. Loose things cause many earthquake injuries; broken bottles cut feet, falling armoires and flying televisions break bones. So fix your bookshelves in place and hang framed art with quake-­proof mountings. Latch cupboards containing breakables like glassware. Keep a headlamp by your bed, because there will probably be a power failure. ‘‘These are the easy, cheap fixes,’’ says Stein, who studied earthquakes and their aftershocks for more than 30 years as a senior scientist with the United States Geological Survey. Last year, he introduced temblor.net, a website and app that enables users to calculate their seismic exposure.

headline: 1915: A Funereal Error
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A widow receives the wrong coffin in 1915.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A widow lady named Wachterhausen, residing at Potsdam, recently had the misfortune to lose her only daughter, Amalia, who was staying at Nice for the benefit of her health. The mother telegraphed to an undertaker in that town ordering an elaborate coffin, and requesting that the remains should be sent home for burial. Just before the funeral on Sunday the mother had the coffin opened, and found that it contained, not her child, but the body of an old officer in Russian uniform. On making inquiries she learned by telegram from Nice that the bodies had been accidentally exchanged. Her daughter’s body had been forwarded to Smolensk in Russia instead of that of the officer. On telegraphing to the Russian authorities Madame Wachterhausen was informed that the body of her daughter had just been buried with great ceremony and military honors. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 12, 1915

But with around 250 gas wells drilled within Denton’s city limits, the subject was thrust upon his consciousness. headline: Inside the List
abstract: Desmond Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his opposition to South African apartheid, has a best seller with “The Book of Forgiving,” written with his daughter Mpho Tutu.
lead_paragraph: Let It Go: Desmond Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his opposition to South African apartheid, turns up on the monthly relationships list on Page 24 this week: “The Book of Forgiving,” written with his daughter Mpho Tutu, is at No. 9. “It doesn’t matter whether you are having trouble moving forward from the wrongs that were done to you, or whether you need the courage to admit the wrongs you have done,” he writes in the introduction. “Forgiveness is nothing less than the way we heal the world. We heal the world by healing each and every one of our hearts.” If that kind of talk triggers flashbacks to your last cardiologist visit — the best way to heal our hearts is probably to eat less bacon — it remains true that Tutu writes with undeniable moral force. And given his experiences leading the Truth and Reconciliation Commission after apartheid’s fall, his prescription is not just simple but consistent and radical. “In South Africa, we chose to seek forgiveness rather than revenge,” he writes. “That choice averted a blood bath. For every injustice, there is a choice. . . . You can choose forgiveness or revenge, but revenge is always costly. Choosing forgiveness rather than retaliation ultimately serves to make you a stronger and freer person.” As it happens, your cardiologist might agree. According to the Johns Hopkins Medicine website, “Studies have found that the act of forgiveness can reap huge rewards for your health, lowering the risk of heart attack; improving cholesterol levels and sleep; and reducing pain, blood pressure and levels of anxiety, depression and stress.”

The world of “War of Two” is often more personal than political, an intimate portrait of Hamilton and Burr as they plunged toward their fatal collision.

headline: William H. Gass’s ‘Eyes’ and John Barth’s ‘Collected Stories’
abstract: Collections of fiction by two American writers over 80 test the boundaries of narrative form.
lead_paragraph: Every so often a magazine with curatorial or prophetic aspirations — say, Granta or The New Yorker — produces a list of the best writers under 40 from a particular nation state. The underlying principle isn’t much more than the logic of the marketplace — the search for the new commodity, explicitly applied to literature. But these lists are haunted by a cluster of unspoken questions about writing’s relationship to longevity. Are writers so short of material that they need to be anointed before midlife? Is novelistic craft not perfected over time? If the answers to these questions aren’t obvious, why not imagine a shadow list that gathers the best American fiction by writers over 80? William H. Gass — 91 years old at the time of writing — would certainly benefit from such a list, since his work typically gestates across decades. He labored on his central achievement, “The Tunnel” (1995), for longer than some acclaimed young novelists have been alive, while his latest volume, “Eyes,” has similarly been in the pipeline at least since the turn of the millennium.

lead_paragraph: The opening paragraph of “Betsy From Pike,” one of the arresting but tender stories in John McManus’s collection “Fox Tooth Heart,” features a three-legged dog, a trailer park in Kentucky, “teenage Satanist rest-area murderers” and a potty-mouthed mom who sleeps all day rather than confront the squalor of her life. Like many of the opening paragraphs of this book, it will have members of Concerned Women for America and other professional worrywarts atwitter. Oh, who am I kidding? They wouldn’t touch this book unless each of its pages was scrubbed with a fresh bar of lye soap.

headline: ‘The New and Improved Romie Futch,’ by Julia Elliott
abstract: Mutated animals, including a giant monster pig, populate a novel that defies categorization.
lead_paragraph: With last year’s genre-bending collection “The Wilds,” Julia Elliott introduced herself as a Flannery O’Connor for the data-mining age: a dark poet of the grotesque and absurd in a world that feels ever more science fictional. “The New and Improved Romie Futch,” her first novel, follows in the same hoof prints, weaving a Southern Gothic fable out of near-future neuroscience and Frankenfood beasts.

headline: ‘The Horse,’ by Wendy Williams
abstract: A biography of the horse and its long, complex partnership with people.
lead_paragraph: In June 1976, a friend of mine and I, passing through Virginia on our way back to Brown, went for a hike in the Smokies, where black bears live. Although my friend would soon become a distinguished science writer, one of the pleasures of our friendship was scaring each other silly. We kept joking about those bears. Halfway up Mount Rogers, we got caught in a thunderstorm and took shelter under a rock face that leaned into canopy. It was a fine hide-out, but it was not ours alone. Under our feet we saw the scat of a large animal, copious and dark — and fresh. Never mind the lightning; we ran.

headline: ‘The Mountain Shadow,’ by Gregory David Roberts
abstract: Tough guys and washed-out expats take the stage in a sequel to “Shantaram.”
lead_paragraph: Gregory David Roberts’s “Shantaram” was an unlikely publishing sensation. Literary purists scoffed at its purple prose; Indian (and many other) readers bristled at its stereotypes and cultural simplifications. The book nonetheless possessed a grittiness and vividness that helped Roberts sell four million copies around the world. Hollywood rights were scooped up (though a film has yet to be made). The book has gone on to occupy a distinctive — and deserving — place in an emerging genre of Bombay noir.

headline: ‘The Death of Cancer,’ by Vincent T. DeVita Jr. and Elizabeth DeVita-Raeburn
abstract: An oncologist reviews issues involved in cancer treatment, and explains his aggressive approach.
lead_paragraph: When I was doing my medical training nearly 20 years ago, there were two kinds of residents: those who were planning on specializing in oncology and those who couldn’t tolerate the subject for even a month. One night when I was on call, I worked with someone in the second camp. He told me about a patient of his, an elderly woman with pancreatic cancer that had grown into her bile duct and metastasized through her intestinal tract. She had been through several rounds of ­chemotherapy without success and was ready to quit treatment, but was afraid to tell her oncologist. “She told me, ‘I don’t want him to think I’m giving up,’ ” my colleague said, obviously disgusted that she didn’t feel comfortable speaking freely about her goals.

Almost 12 years later, The Walkmen have disbanded and Martin, who played bass and organ and contributed lyrics, has two young children. He goes out even less these days, and when he does, it’s more likely to a museum than a bar.

headline: Paleontologists Discover a Poor Cousin to Triceratops
abstract: A fossil recovered in China shows Hualianceratops to have been a plant-eater about the size of spaniel.
lead_paragraph: Paleontologists have discovered a distant relative of Triceratops in western China that lived 160 million years ago. Named Hualianceratops wucaiwanensis, the plant-eater stood on its hind legs and was about the size of a spaniel. Hualianceratops and another dinosaur from the region, named Yinlong downsi, are the two oldest known ceratopsians, so-called horned dinosaurs, although neither the Hualianceratops nor Yinlong had horns. There were dozens of species of ceratopsians, but Triceratops, which lived in North America about 65 million years ago, is the best known. “These small dinosaurs were related to Triceratops, but very distantly,” said Catherine A. Forster, a paleontologist at George Washington University and one of the team who discovered Hualianceratops. She and her colleagues recovered a partial skull and hind leg, and described their findings in the journal PLOS One.

headline: Review: ‘Young Charles Dickens’ Musically Mixes Fact and Fiction
abstract: The show, by New York City Children’s Theater, finds some characters conceived as real people in the author’s life.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine Ebenezer Scrooge, Miss Havisham and the Artful Dodger all occupying the same stage, but that’s the effect of “Young Charles Dickens,” a new musical from New York City Children’s Theater. These characters, though, don’t appear in their fictional guises. Barbara Zinn Krieger, the company’s founder and author of the show’s book and lyrics, has conceived them as real people in Dickens’s life — a cruel boss, a madwoman on the street, a cunning pickpocket — with whom he later populated his novels. Audience members who are old enough can amuse themselves by guessing who’s who. (Bonus points to those recognizing the character from “Bleak House.”)

More than 7,000 completed both the class (47 four- to six-minute videos on cooking for and with children, from easy lunches to quick breakfasts to pantry dinners) and filled out the post-course survey. Obviously, these were people motivated to change, and they did. They reported being more likely to cook dinner at home using fresh ingredients five to seven times during the previous week, and more likely to believe that yesterday’s dinner had been both healthful and enjoyable.

lead_paragraph: For those who enjoy hiking shoreline trails, bayberry is as familiar and comfortable as a favorite hat. It is a touchstone species, a plant with an unpretentious beauty you can count on seeing along a favorite trail. Bayberry is also delightfully fragrant, but only up close. You can’t find bayberry by following the fragrance to its source as you might a rose, wild grapes or even witch hazel. You must crush one of its berries in your fingers or rub one of its leaves under your nose to appreciate its peppery scent. Set against the cold, salty air of the Atlantic coast, it is nature at its most intimate and memorable.

headline: Burundi Military Sites Raided by Gunmen, Renewing Fears of Chaos
abstract: The assaults raised tensions in an African nation pulsing with violence since President Pierre Nkurunziza won a controversial third term in office.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Coordinated attacks by gunmen struck Burundi’s capital before dawn on Friday, the most significant act of violence since a failed coup attempt in May, causing stores to shutter and jittery residents to bolt themselves indoors even as the government sought to assure the incredulous population that daily life was continuing as normal.

headline: Holographic Studios and Kalustyan’s Cafe in Kips Bay
abstract: Kips Bay houses Holographic Studios, perhaps the oldest continuous holographic gallery in the world; and the cafe at Kalustyan’s with Middle Eastern, North African and Armenian specialties.
lead_paragraph: Kips Bay, north of Gramercy Park in Manhattan, was named for an early Dutch farmer, Jacob Kip, and an East River inlet now masked by landfill. Bellevue is its anchor, the oldest continuously operating hospital in the United States, which happens to be two blocks from what is thought to be the oldest continuous gallery of holography in the world, Holographic Studios.

headline: National Front Faces Tougher Climb to Victory in France
abstract: The Socialists withdrew from races across the country to unify with the Republicans against the far-right National Front party, led by Marine Le Pen.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After a week in which she and her far-right National Front party seemed ascendant, Marine Le Pen is heading into Sunday’s second round of French regional elections facing a new and more challenging political equation that will test the appeal of her nationalist, anti-immigrant message.

headline: Spain Arrests Terrorism Suspect in Plot Against Swedish Artist
abstract: Ali Charaf Damache, a dual Algerian and Irish citizen, was arrested in Barcelona and is accused of planning to set up terrorist training camps and kill several Westerners.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain on Friday announced the arrest of a suspect wanted by the United States in connection with terrorism activities, including a failed attempt to kill a Swedish cartoonist who had depicted the Prophet Muhammad with a dog’s body.

headline: Plum Island’s Pink House Inspires a Real Estate Fantasy
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: I daydreamed about how liberating it would be to live alone in high “Grey Gardens” style and own such an extraordinary view. But would there be Wi-Fi?
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, I called a real estate agent in my hometown, Newburyport, Mass., with (as one tends to bring to agents) a fantasy. I wanted to buy the Pink House.

headline: How Do You Talk to Your Children About Being Muslim?
abstract: The Times wants to hear from Muslim parents about how they talk to their children about the rise in anti-Muslim speech as well as attacks by extremists in the name of Islam.
lead_paragraph: It is not an easy time in the United States, or in much of the world, to be Muslim. There are organizations like the Islamic State and Al Qaeda that are committing horrendous acts of terrorism in the name of Islam. At the same time, there are right-wing and nationalist politicians who are scapegoating all Muslims and playing on public fears and anxiety. Donald J. Trump in the United States and Marine Le Pen in France are lashing out at Muslim immigrants and calling them a threat to public safety and cultural identity.

headline: Frank Sinatra: A Hundred Years On, the Voice Resonates Still
abstract: A century after Frank Sinatra’s birth, his influence on American popular music remains formative.
lead_paragraph: Frank Sinatra gave pop music a beating heart.

headline: Protesters Ejected From Donald Trump Event in Manhattan
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Muslim Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

lead_paragraph: Protesters angry at Donald J. Trump’s call to ban foreign Muslims from entering the United States disrupted his appearance on Friday in midtown Manhattan, and security guards forcibly ejected several of the demonstrators.

headline: Review: Saltaire Oyster Bar in Port Chester Offers the Unexpected
abstract: Bobby Will, the restaurant’s creative executive chef, has pulled together unexpected yet harmonious flavors to the meals at the Saltaire Oyster Bar and Fish House.
lead_paragraph: Port Chester’s beautiful old granary warehouse, last occupied by the Willett House restaurant, has been repurposed once again, this time into Saltaire Oyster Bar and Fish House, a stylish, bustling restaurant and bar. The décor is uncluttered and smart, with nautical maps on one wall and heavy loading ropes with serious hooks filling in a corner or two, all leaving room for the luxury of well-spaced tables.

headline: Knicks’ Porzingis Nails the Charm but Aims for Consistency
abstract: Kristaps Porzingis has wowed fans with great games, but his point totals in three games this week — 28, 4 and 13 — demonstrated how inconsistent he can be.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Minutes before the Knicks and the Kings tipped off Thursday night, Vlade Divac, joking with reporters, said that he had some advice for Kristaps Porzingis, the Knicks’ rookie big man from Latvia.

headline: Murder Charges Filed Against Previously Imprisoned Russian Oligarch
abstract: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, once Russia’s richest man and now a resident of London, dismissed the new charges as politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian investigators filed new criminal charges on Friday against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the onetime oil oligarch, critic of President Vladimir V. Putin and former prisoner who lives in exile.

headline: Review: At South End Uncorked, Clever Dishes in a Casual Setting
abstract: A recently opened sibling to South End restaurant combines attractive presentation with tastes and flavors that sing.
lead_paragraph: During a recent dinner at South End Uncorked, which opened in July in downtown New Canaan, the volume seemed to be set at 11, making me feel as though I had to shout to be heard.

headline: Trumpism After Trump
abstract: Donald Trump, the candidate, may or may not last. But the ideas he’s bringing into national circulation are sure to linger.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Donald Trump stood aboard the U.S.S. Yorktown before a sprawling crowd. Earlier in the day, he had introduced a proposal that, in a candidacy notable for its bombast, was his most bombastic yet: a “total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States.” The reaction in the media was instantaneous, enormous — the eyes of the world were on Trump. And yet the man, that night, struck me as far less important than the roar of the crowd that greeted him.

headline: Review: Indian Kitchen in Allendale Leaves the Butter Behind
abstract: Srini Rao and his wife, Himani Pradhan, opened Nirvana Indian Kitchen in April, seeking the healthy, home-cooked Indian food they craved but couldn’t find elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The dal was the first hint that Nirvana Indian Kitchen wasn’t your typical generic curry joint. Fragrant with ginger and cilantro, the soupy yellow lentil stew with peas and bits of diced okra was a recipe from India’s Gujarat region, where my husband Mahir is from. After a few skeptical spoonfuls, he declared it to be as good as his mother’s.

headline: Sexy Fish Caters to London’s Stateless Super-Rich
abstract: The over-the-top restaurant by Richard Caring has become London’s hot restaurant of 2015.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “It is like being punched in the face by Abu Dhabi,” said a reviewer from The Spectator, the weekly journal of the old British establishment.

lead_paragraph: For nearly two centuries, Union Theological Seminary has brought together scholarship and faith on behalf of social justice. headline: Long Island Sports Bars Get a Menu Upgrade
abstract: Gastropubs and sports bars on Long Island are expanding menus to food choices that go beyond wings, pizza and beer.
lead_paragraph: On any given Sunday at Brixx & Barley, a pub in Long Beach that has been open for almost two years, every N.F.L. game is carried live on one of 27 televisions. But the 80-inch screen presiding over the bar is reserved for New York teams.

headline: Give It Up for Pluto
abstract: It may no longer be a planet. But it’s still got a lot going on.
lead_paragraph: IN science, as in other realms, the great and the mighty command our attention and dominate the headlines. See, for example, the recent discoveries of Dreadnoughtus schrani (the biggest dinosaur) and EGS-zs8-1 (the farthest galaxy). But this year, as NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft sped through the outskirts of the solar system, a cherished underdog stole the show: the dwarf planet Pluto.

headline: Artificial-Intelligence Research Center Is Founded by Silicon Valley Investors
abstract: The investors — including Elon Musk, Peter Thiel and Reid Hoffman — said they planned to commit $1 billion to the project long-term, but only small sums to start.
lead_paragraph: A group of prominent Silicon Valley investors and technology companies said on Friday that they would establish an artificial-intelligence research center to develop “digital intelligence” that will benefit humanity.

headline: Finding Refuge for Salmon, Cold Water Preferred
keywords: ['Salmon', 'Global Warming', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: As climate change alters the world of salmon in the Pacific Northwest, a search is beginning for cold-water places for them to hide.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — When Lewis and Clark first encountered the Columbia River in 1805, they wrote about nearby streams so thick with salmon that you could all but walk across on their backs.

headline: One-Thing Shops: Indie Magazines, London
abstract: MagCulture.com opened a brick-and-mortar shop in Clerkenwell to sell the same obscure titles it reviews.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, Jeremy Leslie sat at a makeshift table behind rows of empty shelves, trying to get the music started. “Apart from putting the mags out,” he said, staring halfway between a laptop and a portable speaker, “this is probably the best job.” Leslie was in London’s Clerkenwell neighborhood to prepare for the unveiling of his new shop, a brick-and-mortar extension of magCulture.com, the magazine review site he’s been running since 2006.

headline: The Woman Who Dresses Hollywood’s Leading Men
abstract: Ashley Weston, 28, is the rare Hollywood stylist who works almost exclusively with male actors like Harrison Ford, Vince Vaughn and Jon Hamm.
lead_paragraph: The stylist Ashley Weston moved quickly around the eighth-floor suite of the London West Hollywood hotel the other day, pinning and tucking the folds of an eggplant-colored Zegna suit.

headline: World on Fire: Unquiet Art After 1965 at Purchase
abstract: “After 1965: Art in a Time of Social Unrest,” at the Neuberger Museum, has references to My Lai, napalm, the Watts riots and F.B.I. invasions of privacy.
lead_paragraph: Six oversize panels of Robert Rauschenberg’s 1970 “Currents” series, which hang in a gallery in the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, capture the volatility of an era.

lead_paragraph: On a brisk night in Milan last month, the chic concept store 10 Corso Como was packed with Italian fashion journalists and socialites young and old.

headline: After Skelos and Silver, How to Save Albany
abstract: New York’s political system is corrupt. To fix it, we need a full-time Legislature.
lead_paragraph: Albany — AFTER just a day of deliberation, a jury found former State Senate majority leader Dean G. Skelos and his son guilty on Friday of federal corruption charges. The decision came less than two weeks after another jury handed down a similar verdict against former Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver.

headline: Viola Davis and Edie Falco Talk Race, Sex and Life Before Stardom
abstract: The actresses talk over drinks about the struggles in their early years — waiting tables and eating Spam — and what success means to them today.
lead_paragraph: “It takes 20 years to make an overnight success,” as Eddie Cantor, the old vaudevillian, put it. And judging by the acclaimed careers of Viola Davis and Edie Falco, he wasn’t far off. Interestingly, neither of the actresses would have had it any other way.

headline: ‘Street Life’ at the Heckscher Museum of Art
abstract: More than a decade after acquiring a dynamic painting of a man leaping over a turnstile, the Heckscher has organized a show around it about city life.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a painting of a young man hurtling toward a subway car with an Olympian’s athleticism caught the eye of Lisa Chalif, the curator of the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington. The painting, a 1987 oil on canvas by Don Perlis called “Leaper,” had been donated to the museum in 2002 but had never been put on display, she said, at least not in the 10 years she has been with the museum.

headline: The Global Face of Student Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Names, Geographical', 'Discrimination', 'Apartheid (Policy)']
abstract: In South Africa and other countries around the world, activists are posing the same questions Americans are about who belongs where.
lead_paragraph: Johannesburg — NOT long after I moved from the United States to South Africa six years ago, I took a walk in a city called Bloemfontein. The scale of the downtown is huge, reflecting the ambitions of South Africa’s white settlers. The avenues feel as wide as highways, the department stores soar. Statues of military leaders and politicians from South Africa’s white-ruled past keep watch over the street corners.

headline: Review: ‘Measure for Measure,’ a Comedy of Contradictions
abstract: A six-actor production of Shakespeare’s dark comedy about life’s complexities and contradictions is playing at the Long Wharf Theater.
lead_paragraph: The six-singer a cappella harmony that opens Fiasco Theater’s “Measure for Measure,” now at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, is a prayerful and fitting opening to this Shakespeare play. It’s elegant as a whole but complicated as all get-out under the surface.

headline: Creating a Constellation of Stars in Virtual Reality
abstract: The Magazine’s Maureen Towey on how its latest virtual reality project took flight.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, The New York Times Magazine followed three displaced children in a documentary-style virtual reality experience. For our next major foray into VR, we wanted to push to the other end of the spectrum and see if we could create something fictional. It seemed a natural fit to fold these efforts into our annual Great Performers portfolio, which celebrates the best performers of the year in photo, video and for the first time, virtual reality.

headline: Too Cool for School: Class Pictures Turn Into Photo Shoots
abstract: Students are jumping and jiving for full-body shots with funky backgrounds, color and music. What’s next, a wind machine?
lead_paragraph: The school photo is getting a modern makeover in New York, just in time to mail the grandparents their yearly glossies.

headline: Egypt Is Intensifying Its Crackdown on Journalists, Rights Group Warns
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Committee to Protect Journalists said that the number of detentions of journalists in the country is at its highest point since 1991.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian government has intensified its crackdown against members of the news media in recent weeks, arresting one prominent journalist and preparing to bring another to trial, as the number of reporters detained in Egypt has hit its highest level in decades, according to human rights campaigners and press freedom groups.

headline: Review: ‘The Expanse,’ a Syfy Space Opera Laced With Parables
abstract: This new series is set in an age of depleted natural resources, in which some humans have migrated to Mars and the asteroid belt.
lead_paragraph: In its 23 years, the cable channel now known as Syfy has had exactly one series that became required viewing: “Battlestar Galactica,” which ended in 2009. In the six years since, while AMC, FX, HBO, Netflix and others have defined the parameters of “peak TV,” Syfy’s most recognizable show has probably been “Ghost Hunters,” the reality series about plumbers turned paranormal private eyes.

headline: Paterson Joseph Brings Charles Ignatius Sancho to Life
abstract: One accomplished black Briton honors another in a solo show, “Sancho: An Act of Remembrance,” at BAM Fisher.
lead_paragraph: He was an actor, a composer, a writer and a grocer. He was painted by Gainsborough and corresponded with the novelist Laurence Sterne. He was Charles Ignatius Sancho — black, born on a slave ship and believed to be, in 1774, the first black Briton to cast a vote.

headline: Review: ‘Childhood’s End,’ a Syfy Adaptation of Arthur C. Clarke’s Chilling Futurist Tale

lead_paragraph: “Imagine there’s no countries,” John Lennon sang in that dreamy anthem that gets people all wistful about world peace. “It isn’t hard to do. Nothing to kill or die for, and no religion, too.”

lead_paragraph: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N.J. — In these days of controversy about Muslims in America, a time when the national attitude is being torn between compassion and condemnation, there is a real-life parable to be shared. You know it must be true because it took place at a supermarket in New Jersey, a place too prosaic to sustain any fantasy.

headline: Review: Andrew Norman’s ‘Split,’ a Teeming Premiere From the New York Philharmonic
abstract: Mr. Norman’s new piece for piano and orchestra takes a radical approach to time and structure, reflecting his taste for modern narrative-scrambling techniques.
lead_paragraph: Can the young American composer Andrew Norman keep this up? I’m not just referring to the career roll he’s been on: This week the recording of Mr. Norman’s breathless orchestral work “Play” was nominated for a Grammy Award in the contemporary classical composition category.

headline: Review: ‘Take Care,’ With Audience Participation for All
abstract: At the Flea Theater, the cast insists on interactivity during Todd Shalom and Niegel Smith’s willfully weird play.

keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Bridges and Tunnels']
abstract: Checking in on a Postal Service program to fulfill wishes in letters sent to Santa, after three postal workers were accused of committing fraud under the program.
lead_paragraph: Q. What protections, if any, have been put in place following the Operation Santa fraud at the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue? We’ve been participating for years, but are really considering other options as it is difficult to have confidence that our time, effort and money are reaching the children we are trying to bring a little holiday cheer to.

headline: Qaddafi’s Son Hannibal Is Said to Be Abducted in Lebanon
abstract: The National News Agency said the son, Hannibal Qaddafi, who appeared in a video broadcast on Lebanese television, was seized Thursday by kidnappers.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The youngest son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader deposed and killed four years ago, was abducted in Lebanon and then handed over to security forces by militants seeking to avenge a prominent Lebanese Shiite cleric who disappeared in Libya in the 1970s, the state-run National News Agency said on Friday.

abstract: Donald J. Trump’s dominance in the polls combined with a cluster of second-place candidates looking to topple him has Republicans thinking their convention next summer could be a nerve-racking get-together reminiscent of 1976.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s dominance in the polls, combined with a cluster of second-place candidates looking to topple him, has Republicans thinking their convention next summer could be a nerve-racking get-together reminiscent of 1976.

headline: A Columbia County Nest That Came Fully Feathered
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Barns', 'Hats and Caps', 'Feathers', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: When Elizabeth and Michael Walters first started sifting through the contents of their old barn, the waste threatened to overwhelm them. Then they found the feathers.
lead_paragraph: A farmhouse tucked along the serpentine roads of Columbia County in upstate Ghent, Elizabeth and Michael Walters’s dream home came with a sort of caveat: On the eastern edge of the property sat a dilapidated barn, loaded with years of detritus. The Walterses had no money for a down payment, so the owner agreed to sell on the condition that they would be the ones to empty the barn.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Pot of Gold
abstract: Fashion reflected this magical autumn.
lead_paragraph: The streets and parks of New York are paved in gold — not coins, but ginkgo leaves. It has been the most fantastic prolonged autumn in years, and this week they were still sweeping the golden leaves from the trees around 19th-century Gramercy Park, where there are gas lanterns in front of The Players, the social club. Carriages in Central Park had golden ostrich plumes. Fashion reflected this magical autumn.

headline: Women in Ukraine Walk a New Beat
abstract: In a country where gender equality is a distant dream, female police officers could be a first step toward changing attitudes.
lead_paragraph: In a country where gender equality is a distant dream, female police officers could be a first step toward changing attitudes.

headline: Review: Jory Vinikour, Playing Bach on the Instrument for Which It Was Written
abstract: Mr. Vinikour performed a harpsichord program at Carnegie Hall on Thursday that also included work by Scarlatti, Couperin and others.
lead_paragraph: Only a few decades ago, purists argued that Bach should be played not on the modern piano, but on the harpsichord. But for listeners now accustomed to hearing this composer’s work rendered with the elaborate expressive capabilities of the modern piano, its predecessor’s sound can seem dry and monochromatic.

headline: Review: Creating Contrasts With yMusic, Marcos Balter and Dance
abstract: “Come Around Part IV,” at New York Live Arts, brings together artists from different worlds and disciplines to create and execute a vision together.
lead_paragraph: New York Live Arts, as its longtime visitors know, has changed. Once a destination almost exclusively for dance — in a previous life, it was Dance Theater Workshop — it has opened its doors, under shifting leadership, to a wider range of disciplines and cross-disciplinary programs, for better and for worse.

headline: Review: I’m With Her, Three Americana Virtuosos
abstract: Serene understatement was the hallmark of a concert at the Bowery Ballroom by this trio, made up of Sara Watkins, Sarah Jarosz and Aoife O’Donovan,
lead_paragraph: The harmonies couldn’t have been purer, or the picking more precise, when the trio I’m With Her — an alliance of Americana virtuosos — performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night.

headline: Supreme Court to Review Laws Criminalizing Refusal of Body Substance Tests
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Search and Seizure', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The court will decide whether state efforts to compel breath, blood or urine tests for motorists suspected of drunken driving violate the Fourth Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether states can make it a crime for motorists suspected of drunken driving to refuse breath, blood or urine tests. Thirteen states have such laws.

headline: Mobilizing Voters in New York’s Housing Projects
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections']
abstract: Renovations are underway at the Queensbridge Houses in Long Island City, which might not have come to pass without initiatives to reach out to voters in the city’s housing projects.
lead_paragraph: Located in a stretch of Long Island City, in Queens, close to but psychologically distant from new glass apartment towers that offer rock-climbing walls and in certain instances call themselves “clubs,” the Queensbridge Houses make up the largest public housing project in the country. Built near the East River in the late 1930s, they contain 96 low-rise buildings and more than 7,000 people. Music critics have noted that, on a per-capita basis, Queensbridge — at various points home to Nas, Capone, Tragedy Khadafi, Marley Marl — is responsible for unleashing more hip-hop talent than any other location in the world.
