lead_paragraph: Q. I tried the Rebuild command to find missing messages in Mac Mail on the El Capitan version (OS X 10.11), but it didn’t fix my problem. What else can I try?

headline: ‘Making a Murderer’: Watched It All? Share Your Theories.
keywords: ['Television', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: What does everyone think really happened here?
lead_paragraph: For armchair detectives, Netflix’s “Making a Murderer” is delicious fodder: 10 hours of a true-crime documentary, smartly released by the streaming service over the holidays, when free time is abundant. After watching the story of Steven Avery, it’s difficult not to immediately postulate theories and throw things at your screen as you rage against the imperfections of the American justice system.

headline: Trial of Chad’s Ex-President Brings Harrowing Accounts of Abuse
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Men and women from Chad testified about their ordeals in a Senegal court, where Hissène Habré is being tried for atrocities during his rule between 1982 and 1990.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The witness, a slight middle-aged woman, wanted to tell the court about something that had happened to her, something terrible that she said she had kept to herself for more than 30 years. As she faced the judges, she was just steps away from the man on trial, Hissène Habré, once Chad’s all-powerful and much-feared president.

headline: Blake Bortles’s Huge Leap Bodes Well for the Jaguars
abstract: Despite a 5-10 record, the Jaguars should be encouraged by the improvement of Bortles, 23, who ranks second in N.F.L. passing touchdowns and sixth in passing yards.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Jacksonville Jaguars quarterback Blake Bortles had a nondescript rookie campaign. He finished well below average in most passing metrics and had the lowest passer rating in the N.F.L. among qualifying quarterbacks.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: CENSORS AT WORK: How States Shaped ­Literature, by Robert Darnton. (Norton, $17.95.) To understand the longstanding human predilection for censorship, Darnton examines three historical cases of political interference with literature: the monarchy in 18th-century France; British colonial rule in 19th-century India; and the 20th-century Communist dictatorship in East Germany. Exploring the various justifications governments have invoked in defense of censorship, the author draws inferences about its long-term cultural impact.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHT SCYTHE: Selected Poems, by Tomas Transtromer. Translated by Patty Crane. (Sarabande Books, $17.95.) Until his death last year, the 2011 Nobelist was one of Europe’s greatest poets, producing work of austere beauty and mystery.

headline: Keeping Up With Firefox Updates
abstract: Firefox updates busily, about once every six weeks. If you’d like to see what they just did, or a calendar of what’s next, here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why does the Firefox browser on my computer constantly update itself? Is there a way to see what is actually being changed?

headline: Manila Social Club
abstract: Nostalgia suffuses the dishes at this Filipino restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Nostalgia suffuses the dishes at this Filipino restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: At Manila Social Club in Williamsburg, Rambling Filipino Cuisine
abstract: Nostalgia suffuses the finest dishes from the chef Björn DelaCruz.
lead_paragraph: Björn DelaCruz never learned the name of the dish he ate at a roadside shack under a narra tree, not far from his grandmother’s orchid farm in Davao Oriental, the Philippines. It was simple, made with carabao (water buffalo) milk, chayote and fish likely caught in the river running alongside.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Clint Emerson’s “100 Deadly Skills” includes handy pointers, like how to build a bulletproof vest out of duct tape and books.
lead_paragraph: Be Prepared: If your New Year’s resolutions include acquiring the know-how to build your own stun gun, dispose of a body and trick facial-recognition technology — in other words, the usual — you might want to skip the advice list and head straight to the monthly espionage list, available online, where Clint Emerson’s “100 Deadly Skills” was No. 2 in December. Emerson is a former member of the Navy SEALs who served with Chris Kyle, of “American Sniper” fame, and now runs his own security consulting firm in the Dallas suburbs. Among the 100 lessons in his crisply illustrated manual are such handy pointers as how to turn a plastic water bottle into a gun silencer and, for bibliophiles, how to build a bulletproof vest out of duct tape and books. “You have to learn from the predators,” Emerson told Texas Monthly this fall, “because your natural-born instinct won’t be good enough.”

headline: ‘A Strange Business,’ by James Hamilton
abstract: Hamilton’s history examines a crucial period in the evolution of the art market.
lead_paragraph: James Hamilton’s “A Strange Business” — the title is taken from an observation about the art market made late in life by the brilliant British painter J. M. W. Tur­ner — is every bit as quirky a book as you might expect from a onetime fellow at St. Antony’s College, Oxford. It has 31 pages of endnotes; a 14-page index; and six pages of bibliography, in reduced type, including a section for primary source material, one for secondary source material and another for “manuscripts consulted.” There are also four tiny-type pages devoted to recounting for the befuddled reader the names of the 180 or so “Dramatis Personae” that get name-checked continually, from George Ackermann, the art dealer and publisher, to John Young, the ­engraver and curator.

headline: After a Tumultuous Year for Investors, the Experts Look Ahead
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Commodities']
abstract: Turning to some of 2015’s most successful investors and analysts for an annual look at what to expect next year.
lead_paragraph: The last year was a treacherous one for investors, including some top hedge fund and asset managers. Much of what happened in global markets can be traced to falling oil and commodity prices, which rippled through the economies and markets of most major oil-producing nations.

headline: 21 Injured on Air Canada Flight After Sudden Turbulence
abstract: Passengers on a flight from Shanghai to Toronto on Wednesday were thrown from their seats, some hitting the ceiling, as the plane suddenly plummeted. It then made an emergency landing in Calgary.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Sudden and intense turbulence during an Air Canada flight on Wednesday threw passengers out of their seats, with some hitting the ceiling of the airplane, and resulted in numerous injuries.

headline: ‘Up Against the Night,’ by Justin Cartwright
abstract: A fictional South African wrestles with his Boer lineage.
lead_paragraph: In the 1830s, the Boer commander ­Pieter Mauritz Retief led part of the Great Trek out of the British-occupied Cape Colony, intending to settle in Zululand, only to be massacred by the Zulu king’s warriors. Many years later, Retief’s legacy — a thorny mix of heroism, nationalism and racism — haunts his fictional descendant, Frank McAllister, the present-day narrator of Justin Cartwright’s latest novel, “Up Against the Night.” The battle provides the only sound archival root for what becomes a gratifyingly unsound psychological odyssey.

headline: ‘One Out of Two,’ by Daniel Sada
abstract: This novel’s twin heroines are so close they share a lover.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican writer Daniel Sada’s second novel to appear in English, “One Out of Two,” is a spry addition to the genre of spinster sister fiction. Sada, who died in 2011, was as prolific as he was mischievous. Between his birth in Mexicali in 1953 and his death at 58, he published 20 books of fiction and poetry, all of them consistently unpredictable. In “One Out of Two,” Sada’s interest in spinster escapades is foremost in the opportunities they create for playing around with sexual tension and transgression.

headline: ‘Suspicious Minds,’ by Rob Brotherton
abstract: We are hard-wired to believe that nothing happens by accident.
lead_paragraph: For all the talk of Donald Trump’s unpresidential behavior, the Republican enfant terrible does share one notable trait with that paragon of presidentiality, George Washington: a fondness for conspiracy theories. Washington once wrote in a letter that he believed an Illuminati conspiracy was at work in America, while Trump is the figurehead of the birther movement, which claims Barack Obama is not a natural-born American citizen. The psychologist and science journalist Rob Brotherton’s new book, “Suspicious Minds: Why We Believe Conspiracy ­Theories,” helps explain why someone with such seemingly outlandish views can gain widespread public support. It turns out we are all conspiracy theorists.

headline: ‘Bird,’ by Noy Holland
abstract: A mother’s quotidian rhythm is punctuated by longing for a bittersweet past.
lead_paragraph: After three widely praised story collections, Noy Holland’s first novel, “Bird,” is a whirling and feverish illustration of how much time can be contained in the present moment. A master of the domestic, Holland takes us again into that sphere: into the life of Bird, a stay-at-home mother of two children, as she moves through the events of a single day. Bird readies her son for school, sees her husband out the door, takes a bath with the baby. An old friend calls, and they share stories about the past. Bird takes the baby for a walk, and they stop by a pond, enjoying some time on the grass. Returning home, she flips through a photo album, talks on the phone again and hangs up in time to share the last moments of sunlight with the baby before greeting her son at the school bus.

headline: ‘Martin John,’ by Anakana Schofield
abstract: Imagining a sex offender, and his mother, as he structures his world to both accommodate and suppress his urges.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often you feel sympathetically disposed toward flashers, gropers, public masturbators or punchers of women’s private parts, and in fairness, you don’t often feel it while reading “Martin John” either — but you sometimes do, which makes Anakana Schofield either an extremely persuasive apologist for the sexually aberrant or a very fine novelist.

headline: ‘Abba Eban: A Biography,’ by Asaf Siniver
abstract: A biography of Abba Eban, who spoke eloquently for Israel at the United Nations and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: In December 1955, following Syrian har­assment of Israeli fishermen on the Sea of Galilee, Israel carried out a large attack on Syrian military positions, killing 50 soldiers and capturing 30. Abba Eban, Israel’s eloquent and admired representative to the United Nations, thought the response was over the top and wrote a letter to Prime Minister David Ben-­Gurion condemning the raid. At the United Nations, meanwhile, Eban defended the operation, assailing Syria’s implacable hostility. Ben-Gurion wrote back to Eban saying he himself had had doubts about the retaliation but “when I read the full text of your brilliant defense of our action in the Security Council, all my doubts were set to rest. You have convinced me that we were right after all.”

headline: ‘The English and Their History,’ by Robert Tombs
abstract: An encyclopedic retelling of the nation’s history tracks the changing ways it has been interpreted by the English themselves.
lead_paragraph: Even in free countries it is sometimes necessary to alter the past to suit the present. For instance, I recall the day at my English boarding school in the early 1960s when our sober, patriotic old history books were gathered up and carted away to a storeroom. In their place we were handed bright, optimistic replacements, with a good deal less to say about the empire, the Protestant martyrs or what we had been taught without embarrassment to call the Glorious Revolution.

headline: ‘Infectious Madness,’ by Harriet A. Washington
abstract: A survey of research presses the case that infections, even in the womb, are linked to mental illnesses like schizophrenia.
lead_paragraph: One hundred and sixty odd years ago, Ignaz Semmelweis realized that physicians who didn’t wash their hands were carrying tiny germs from bedside to bedside and causing the childbed fever that killed many women. After doctors began washing their hands, fewer women died. The series of realizations in the 19th century that germs — bacteria and viruses — caused diseases like cholera and tuberculosis and influenza ushered in modern medicine. Mortality rates declined; children lived longer. Germ theory had a dramatic clarity to it. It pushed medicine away from holistic conceptions of illness as imbalance toward conceptions of illness as a specific entity. You get the germ, you fall sick, you take antibiotics or fight it off (or die). Ironically, though, the tidiness of this relationship helped obscure cases where germs may have less direct but still devastating effects — a complex reality we are now beginning to understand better.

headline: Thomas Perry’s ‘Forty Thieves,’ and More
abstract: A married couple, former detectives, are targeted by a husband-and-wife team of assassins in Perry’s new thriller.
lead_paragraph: Nick and Nora Charles they’re not. But while Sid and Veronica Abel may be lacking in urbanity, these private investigators are no less brainy and far better marksmen. Appearing for the first time in Thomas Perry’s new thriller, FORTY THIEVES (Mysterious, $26), these former Los Angeles police detectives have been married for over 30 years and have children and grandchildren. That confers on them the wisdom of the ancients, along with the cloak of invisibility in a youth-obsessed society, which suits them just fine. (“Do you have any idea what gray hair is worth in our business?”)

headline: BBC Websites Said to Be Target of Online Attack
abstract: The company’s websites and popular video-on-demand service were offline for roughly three hours; the BBC’s television and radio stations were not affected.
lead_paragraph: The British Broadcasting Corporation said on Thursday that its digital services had been shut down temporarily in what its news operation described as a hacking attack.

keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Six others were given prison terms in the killing of Rajib Haider, a secular blogger and activist who was a critic of the Islamist party Jamaat-e-Islami.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A court in Bangladesh sentenced two people to death and six others to prison terms on Thursday for killing a secular blogger and activist in 2013, the first sentences in a series of  killings of bloggers in Bangladesh.

headline: Food Memoir
abstract: New books include “Voracious: A Hungry Reader Cooks Her Way Through Great Books” and “Slice Harvester: A Memoir in Pizza.”
lead_paragraph: HOW TO COOK A MOOSEA Culinary MemoirBy Kate Christensen292 pp. Islandport, $24.95.

headline: Pentagon Curbs Use of Psychologists With Guantánamo Detainees
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Detainees', 'Torture', 'Interrogations']
abstract: The change is in response to psychologists’ strict new ethics rules, Pentagon officials said, in the latest fallout after years of recriminations over the profession’s role in harsh interrogations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military has sharply curtailed the use of psychologists at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in response to strict new professional ethics rules of the American Psychological Association, Pentagon officials said.

headline: Ted Cruz Raises Almost $20 Million in Year-End Surge
abstract: Mr. Cruz and Ben Carson were the first of the 2016 presidential candidates to release details of how much money they raised during the final fund-raising quarter of the year.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz raised significantly more money in the final three months of the year while Ben Carson maintained his pace in fund-raising during that period, according to numbers released by the Republican presidential hopefuls’ campaigns.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: You, New and Improved
abstract: This week, Heather Havrilesky talks about Amy Cuddy’s “Presence” and Shonda Rhimes’s “Year of Yes,” and Michael Ian Black discusses “Navel Gazing.” Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Heather Havrilesky talks about Amy Cuddy’s “Presence” and Shonda Rhimes’s “Year of Yes,” and Michael Ian Black discusses “Navel Gazing.” Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: 1966 | ‘We Could Not Move, We Could Not Take Cover’
abstract: Losing his trousers, and almost his life, during a firefight in Vietnam 50 years ago, R.W. Apple Jr. began to build his legend as a correspondent.
lead_paragraph: It took decades to forge the legend of the correspondent R. W. Apple Jr. — a man known for his “Dickensian byline, Churchillian brio and Falstaffian appetites,” according to Todd Purdum, a former Times reporter who wrote Mr. Apple’s obituary.

headline: Fund-Raising Pleas Get Desperate as Year Winds Down
abstract: It’s that special time of year, the one where email inboxes are inundated with pleading and repetitive donation requests from political campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz has “nowhere else to turn.” Jeb Bush is “counting on you.” Senator Marco Rubio “needs you to hear this.” Senator Rand Paul “needs all hands on deck.”

headline: Chris Christie’s Punch Lines vs. Marco Rubio’s Polish on Iowa Campaign Trail
abstract: Over two days in Iowa in the final stretch before the caucuses, the two political thoroughbreds showed strikingly different campaign styles.
lead_paragraph: MUSCATINE, Iowa — It was the same question, on the same topic, asked on the same day to two different candidates: How, as president, would you hold down the crushing cost of a college education?

headline: ‘Manspreading,’ ‘Vape’ and ‘So’: Hated Words for 2016
abstract: The annual survey from Lake Superior State University in Michigan compiles the nominations.
lead_paragraph: If you are still trying to decide on a New Year’s resolution, there are some people in Michigan who might be able to help: Promise never to use the word “problematic” again.

headline: Polls Show Attacks on Bill Clinton May Only Help Hillary Clinton
abstract: Donald J. Trump made clear this week that noting was off limits when it comes attacking the Clintons, sexual indiscretions of the past are fair game in an election year.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump made clear this week that nothing was off limits when it came to attacking the Clintons, dusting off names like Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones while calling former President Bill Clinton one of “the great abusers of the world.” Sexual indiscretions of the past, he said, are fair game in an election year.

headline: Soaking The Rich, Slightly
abstract: Why they hate Obama.
lead_paragraph: Good catch by Josh Barro. It’s been clear for a while that taxes on top incomes went up significantly in 2013; but we’ve had to rely on estimates of the change, not actual numbers. Now the actual numbers on income taxes are in, and sure enough, fairly big hikes at the top.

headline: Over 50 and Buying a First Home
abstract: Older first-time home buyers belong to an exclusive club, given that the median age of first-time buyers in 2015 was 31.
lead_paragraph: Edith Shapiro was 36 when she and her husband, Nathan, moved in 1967 to a brand-new rental building at 200 East 62nd Street. Back then, $725 per month got them a four-bedroom duplex with four and a half baths.

headline: The Red Tape of New Windows in New York
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Windows']
abstract: In many parts of the country, replacing old, drafty windows is as simple as picking them out and scheduling a contractor. But that’s not the case in New York City.
lead_paragraph: In many parts of the country, replacing old, drafty, noisy windows is as simple as selecting products at a home improvement store and scheduling a contractor to install them. But that’s not the case in New York, where window replacement, like so many facets of home renovation, is governed by rules and procedures.

headline: Fino Sherry, for the Undaunted
abstract: Versatile yet complicated, fino asks to be explored with an open mind.
lead_paragraph: Stick your nose into a glass of fino sherry and you may be in for a shock. Years of enjoying the usual sorts of fruity reds and whites will not have prepared you for the wave (some may say assault) of aromas. Instead of the gentle sweetness that sherry novices may expect, what arises is bone dry, pungent and savory, almost the antithesis of sweet and fruity.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Marsannay Burgundy
abstract: Inviting readers to taste one of the more moderately priced Burgundies.
lead_paragraph: Next up, we visit what many consider the spiritual center for much that we worship about red wine: Burgundy.

headline: Iran Denounces U.S. Sanctions Over Missiles, Saying It Will Build More
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani, responding to American plans for new sanctions over Iran’s tests of missiles, told his Defense Ministry to build more of them.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s president denounced the United States on Thursday for suggesting the possibility of new sanctions over Iranian missiles, and he ordered his Defense Ministry to respond by swiftly building more of them.

headline: Top Ben Carson Aides Quit Amid Campaign Turmoil
abstract: Ben Carson’s troubled presidential campaign saw fresh upheaval on New Year’s Eve as his campaign manager and spokesman both abruptly resigned.
lead_paragraph: New upheaval engulfed Ben Carson’s troubled presidential campaign on Thursday as his campaign manager and his spokesman resigned abruptly after a deep rift with an outside adviser to the candidate.

headline: The Selfish Side of Gratitude
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'News and News Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: How to make yourself feel good by adopting an attitude of thankfulness.
lead_paragraph: THIS holiday season, there was something in the air that was even more inescapable than the scent of pumpkin spice: gratitude.

headline: Seinfeld and Obama, Chatting in a Corvette
abstract: Jerry Seinfeld asked the president about his underwear during an episode of his show “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama wears one brand of underwear, always the same color. He shaves before working out in the morning. And he picks out his own suit.

headline: Murder Isn’t Black or White
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Confessions', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: I want justice for my cousins. I don’t want to talk about race.
lead_paragraph: IT was the spring of 1991 — more than two decades before Ferguson, Mo., would become a national symbol of racism — when my parents took my siblings and me to visit their hometown, St. Louis. We spent the week hanging out with our cousins, with whom we were close. I was 16, too young to tag along when, the night before we were supposed to return home to Maryland, my 19-year-old brother, Tom Cummins, and our cousins, Julie and Robin Kerry, were brutally attacked by four strangers. Julie was 20, Robin, 19.

headline: Review: In ‘Stories I Tell Myself,’ Life as Hunter S. Thompson’s Son
abstract: Juan F. Thompson’s memoir is a careful yet harrowing account of a father-and-son relationship that grew very dark before it began to admit hints of light.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy growing up a shy, sensitive, bullied, Dungeons & Dragons-playing child, the kind of friendless boy who hates sports, becomes a vegetarian and in college eats alone in the cafeteria, pretending to read a newspaper while dying inside.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘45 Years’
abstract: Andrew Haigh narrates a sequence from his film featuring Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Haigh narrates a sequence from his film featuring Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.

headline: Same Trail, Diverging Styles
abstract: Chris Christie and Marco Rubio showed strikingly different styles over two days of campaigning in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie and Marco Rubio showed strikingly different styles over two days of campaigning in Iowa.

headline: Allen Lacy, a Professor Turned Gardening Columnist, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Lacy, a philosophy professor who sowed his cultivated wit and wisdom for The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal, wrote or edited 10 books on gardening.
lead_paragraph: Allen Lacy, an accidental gardening columnist whose cramped backyard inspired practical advice on down-to-earth subjects like expunging crab grass and erudite cerebrations about far-flung fields like global warming, died last Sunday at his home in Linwood, N.J. He was 80.

headline: You Can Now Call Him Sir Matthew (Bourne)
abstract: Matthew Bourne, Imelda Staunton and Damon Albarn are among those receiving New Year’s Honors in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The choreographer Matthew Bourne, the actress Imelda Staunton, the Blur frontman Damon Albarn, the ballerina Tamara Rojo and the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon are all on this year’s New Year’s Honors 2016, the list of awards announced by the British cabinet office to those who have distinguished themselves in a variety of professional or charitable fields. (These are wide-ranging, and this year include “honorable services to snooker” among many others.)

headline: The Next Big Voting-Rights Fight
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: “One person, one vote” has long been the logic behind drawing legislative districts. But a new case faces the Supreme Court with a huge question: Who, exactly, counts as a "person”?
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, The New York Times Magazine has chronicled the long campaign that led to the Supreme Court’s 2013 nullification of the Voting Rights Act’s most powerful provision — its Section 5 — and the consequences that decision has had for minority voters. As I’ve written in our Disenfranchised series, the gutting of Section 5 facilitated an onslaught of restrictive new laws that made voting disproportionately harder for minorities across the country, marking the biggest setback to minority voting rights in the half-century since President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Fire Engulfs Luxury Dubai Hotel, Forcing Evacuation of New Year’s Crowd
abstract: A 63-story luxury hotel in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, burst into flames on Thursday evening. Over a dozen people were reported to have been injured.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — A luxury hotel skyscraper in Dubai was engulfed in flames after a fire broke out Thursday, causing an evacuation of a large crowd from the downtown area that had gathered for New Year’s Eve.

headline: Andrew Haigh Narrates a Scene From ‘45 Years’
abstract: The writer and director discusses a scene featuring Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.
lead_paragraph: A couple (Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay) face a hurdle in their lengthy marriage in the drama “45 Years,” written and directed by Andrew Haigh. The British filmmaker’s previous film, “Weekend,” looked at the the brief relationship between two men after a one-night stand. In a recent interview at The Times, Mr. Haigh discussed how those films were alike and his decision to follow up a gay-themed film with one on heterosexual characters. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: On the 101st Floor, Saying ‘I Do’
abstract: Haley Swindal, an actress, and Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent, were married Dec. 12 high above Manhattan in One World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: Haley Swindal, an actress, and Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent, were married Dec. 12 high above Manhattan in One World Trade Center.

abstract: Haley Swindal and Jack Tantleff were enmeshed in theater life thousands of miles apart, but made time to grow close.
lead_paragraph: Ever since his divorce in 2008, Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent in New York, had struggled to find someone to fill the role of partner in his life.

headline: Video Review: The Scion iM Is Proud to Be a Hatchback
abstract: Europeans have been more willing to embrace the hatchback style, but the iM’s ample room and alert driving feel could change some minds in America.
lead_paragraph: THEY’VE been embraced by Europeans and shunned by Americans. Lately, this could pertain to any number of things, but right now I’m describing hatchbacks.

headline: Ants Can Change Their Roles, Study Finds
abstract: A study published this week found that treating ants with chemicals can alter the responsibilities they take on in a colony.
lead_paragraph: Among Florida carpenter ants there are the so-called majors, brawny soldiers that guard the colony, and the smaller minors that act as foragers. But membership in these castes is not set in stone, a new study found.

headline: Gene Editing Offers Hope for Treating Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, Studies Find
abstract: Three research groups, working independently of one another, reported in the journal Science on Thursday that a powerful new gene-editing technique could treat Duchenne muscular dystrophy in mice.
lead_paragraph: After decades of disappointingly slow progress, researchers have taken a substantial step toward a possible treatment for Duchenne muscular dystrophy with the help of a powerful new gene-editing technique.

headline: Test Your ‘Downton Abbey’ Drama Quotient
abstract: “Downton Abbey” ends its six-season run on Sunday. How well do you know the characters and their tortured pasts?
lead_paragraph: “Downton Abbey” ends its six-season run on Sunday. How well do you know the characters and their tortured pasts?

headline: Russia Plans Survey in Crimea on Ukraine Electricity Contract
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Crimea residents will be asked if they want to accept a new electricity contract with Ukraine, even if it states the Black Sea peninsula is part of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In an echo of the referendum in 2014 on whether to join Russia, residents of Crimea are being asked if they want to reaffirm their choice.

headline: Jeb Bush Courts Iowa Supporters at Rose Bowl in California
abstract: With most political eyes on Iowa right now, and most Iowa eyes on the Rose Bowl — where their beloved Hawkeyes are taking on Stanford on New Year’s Day — the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush is heading to Pasadena, Calif., where the big game will be held.

headline: F.B.I. Is Asked to Investigate Chicago Police Shooting That Left 2 Dead
abstract: The Cook County state’s attorney, Anita Alvarez, sought the F.B.I.’s help after the deaths of Quintonio LeGrier and Bettie Jones last week.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The top county prosecutor here Thursday asked the F.B.I. to investigate the fatal shooting of two people by a Chicago police officer over the weekend, and Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s administration separately released a trove of emails showing how City Hall aides scrambled for months to address an earlier police shooting that was captured on video.

headline: Rochester Man Charged With Planning Attack on Behalf of ISIS
abstract: Emanuel L. Lutchman, 25, was arrested and accused of preparing to stage a New Year’s Eve machete attack on diners at a local restaurant.
lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old man in Rochester has been arrested and charged with preparing to stage a New Year’s Eve machete attack on diners at a local restaurant on behalf of the Islamic State.

headline: A Turbulent Year in the Music Business
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: For the music industry, 2015 was a year of huge hits, big battles behind the scenes and the continuing evolution of an industry that has been transformed by technology and the Internet.
lead_paragraph: For the music industry, 2015 was a year of huge hits, big battles behind the scenes and the continuing evolution of an industry that has been transformed by technology and the Internet.

headline: The Last (and Most Expensive) Night of the Year
keywords: ['New Year', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Restaurants', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Surge pricing was in effect on everything from breadsticks to bar stools as restaurants and nightclubs got ready for New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: Vegas Dave knows what it costs to ring in the new year, Vegas Dave-style.

headline: Jewish-Arab Love Story Excluded From Israeli Classrooms
abstract: The Ministry of Education decided not to include the novel “Borderlife” by Dorit Rabinyan for high school literature classes, setting off a debate.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Ministry of Education has decided not to include a novel about a romance between an Israeli woman and a Palestinian man on the list of required reading for Hebrew high school literature classes, prompting a stormy debate over how Israeli society deals with its cultural divides.

headline: Review: Metropolitan Museum Looks at Photos That May Last
abstract: “Reconstructions: Recent Photographs and Video From the Met Collection” includes works by Moyra Davey, Erica Baum and others.
lead_paragraph: It is contemporary photography roundup time in New York, with major exhibitions appearing concurrently at the Museum of Modern Art (“Ocean of Images: New Photography 2015”) and the Guggenheim (“Photo-Poetics: An Anthology”). The Met’s contribution, “Reconstructions: Recent Photographs and Video From the Met Collection,” is not framed as a showcase of what’s new, hot or trending, but it relates both subtly and significantly to these two exhibitions. The show includes 18 works by 15 artists acquired during the past seven years – work that Met curators think will endure historically.

headline: The New Exponential Festival Opens in Brooklyn
abstract: The new 18-day theater festival, which begins on Jan. 13, in the combined effort of several Brooklyn theaters seeking broader exposure for local work.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Theresa Buchheister, a founder of the experimental theater company Title: Point, and Eliza Bent, a playwright and performer, spent an evening lamenting all the shows they’d missed — friends’ plays that had overlapped with their own, short runs they’d discovered too late. “These were shows that should happen again,” Ms. Bent remembered insisting. But when? And where?

headline: Review: Praying to the Heavens, Looking at the Stars and Revising a Service
abstract: Daniel Felsenfeld presented “Astrophysical Mass” as part of a program to create new Mass settings and texts.
lead_paragraph: Starting around the 1960s, radical revisions to the Christian liturgy have resulted in a more accessible service and a great deal of music for the Mass. But not much of it has been by significant composers.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Jan. 1, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Concussion,” “Anomalisa” and “Daddy’s Home.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Concussion,” “Anomalisa” and “Daddy’s Home.”

headline: Review: ‘Maestà,’ Piecing Together Part of a Lost Legacy
abstract: This exhibition of a Gaddi altarpiece also offers a lesson in how the New-York Historical Society and other museums should safeguard their patrimony.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you don’t know what you have until it’s gone. That’s a lesson viewers might take away from “Maestà: Gaddi’s Triptych Reunited,” a tiny exhibition at the New-York Historical Society that inadvertently prompts thought about museums and their responsibilities.

headline: A Recovering but Changed Auto Industry
abstract: United States automakers have emerged from their worst crisis in a generation, but they have lost much along the way.
lead_paragraph: United States automakers have emerged from their worst crisis in a generation, but they have lost much along the way.

headline: Auto Industry Sales Explode in an Ever-Changing Market
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: The dominance of the three Detroit giants has slipped and foreign brands like Toyota and Kia have filled the gap.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Automakers have enjoyed an unequaled run of success in the United States because of pent-up consumer demand, cheap gas prices and low interest rates. But despite record sales, manufacturers must continue updating their vehicles and improving technology to keep the good times rolling.

headline: Our Favorite Styles Photos of 2015
abstract: A look at some of the year’s most striking Styles section images.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the year’s most striking Styles section images.

headline: In Reversal, Twitter to Let Politwoops Collect Politicians’ Deleted Tweets
abstract: The social network had revoked Politwoops’s access to its API earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Politwoops will once again be able to collect and publish the deleted tweets of American politicians after Twitter announced Thursday that it reached a deal with the organizations that run the website.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Lush Colors
keywords: ['Coats and Jackets', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The richness of colors, particularly pastels and flower patterns on winter coats, often reflects the hidden treasures of gemstones and of vegetables sliced open, revealing an intense color inside.
lead_paragraph: As we embark on the new year, the richness of colors, particularly pastels and flower patterns on winter coats, often reflects the hidden treasures of gemstones and of vegetables sliced open, revealing an intense color inside. A spectrum that ranged from amethyst to lavender was mirrored in cabbage roses. Blacks and grays remain a foundation of fashion for practical reasons.

headline: Escaped Convicts in Argentina Shoot 2 Police Officers
abstract: Inmates who escaped from a prison in Buenos Aires Province wounded the officers, officials said, as two politicians blamed each other for the breakout.
lead_paragraph: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina — Three escaped convicts shot and wounded two traffic police officers on Thursday, officials said, after a prison break that set off a round of finger-pointing between feuding politicians.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Daddy’s Home.”

abstract: Whether you’re hoping to improve your body or your mind — or just add to your cocktail conversation repertory — this weekend is full of events for self-improvement.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re hoping to improve your body or your mind — or even just add to your cocktail conversation repertory — this weekend has plenty of events for self-improvement that, while opening the door for commitment, ask for nothing upfront.

headline: Friday File: When the Ball First Dropped on New Year’s Eve
abstract: Weekend entertainments from the archives of The New York Times, including the beginning of the Times Square celebration more than 100 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The last newspaper printed before The New York Times left its building on Park Row appeared on New Year’s Day, 1905.

headline: Spurs Get a Laugh Track to Go With Their Five Titles
abstract: Matt Hill, who produces the animated web series “Spurs Special Forces,” is a shining example of the way some comedy writers are having fun with the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson, or, rather, a coarsely animated version of him, is sitting in a hotel room, threatening Gregg Popovich, the San Antonio Spurs coach, and pressing him to join the Knicks with a big-city sales pitch.

abstract: Seven of the stranger things that vexed the Internet in 2015 — and what they (maybe) tell us about ourselves.

headline: Review: Squeak Carnwath Speaks With Her Varied Palette
abstract: Ms. Carnwath’s exhibit at Jane Lombard Gallery is her first solo show in New York in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Over the decades, Squeak Carnwath has cultivated a distinctive blend of disparate 1970s art movements, including New Image painting, Conceptual Art and above all Process Art. In her first solo show in New York in over a decade, her paintings fluently speak several languages at once. Areas of flat color are adrift with abstract and representational elements as well as writing — passing thoughts, the news, quips — often partly submerged in the shuffle of erasures and new additions. Everything contributes to the commentary. Tracts of cursive consider the income gap or light pollution, while little blocks of color allude to abstraction and a compass rose conjures cartography and sign painting.

headline: Evening Hours | The Debutante Cotillion
abstract: A festive tradition continues.
lead_paragraph: A festive tradition continues.

headline: Review: Rudolf Stingel at Nahmad Contemporary, Making Crowd-Sourced Art
abstract: Mr. Stingel presents Styrofoam works splashed with acid or decorated with graffiti by visitors.
lead_paragraph: By 2000, the Italian-born painter Rudolf Stingel had made what he called paintings by covering floors or walls with bright orange carpet, and had sold D.I.Y. abstract painting kits. He then began to adopt more traditional formats while maintaining his hands-off attitude. The results, as demonstrated by the 10 paintings from 2000 to 2003 in this exhibition, continue to startle, taunt and seduce.

headline: N.F.L. Week 17 Previews and Picks
abstract: If the Jets win at Buffalo, they’re in the playoffs. If they lose, they will need the Steelers to lose to the 3-12 Browns.
lead_paragraph: Vikings (10-5) at Packers (10-5)

headline: Review: In ‘The Himalayas,’ Two Climbers Form an Indelible Bond
abstract: In this adventure film, an experienced climber and his protégé form a lifelong bond when they reach the world’s third highest peak together.
lead_paragraph: “The Himalayas” is a broad comedy, a buddy movie, a mountain climbing adventure and a cornball weepie, not always in proportions that go well together. Inspired by a real-life mission to recover the bodies of mountaineering compatriots who died on Mount Everest in 2004, it spans roughly a dozen years in the lives of a team of South Korean climbers.

headline: ‘Dog Days’ Is Centerpiece of Prototype Festival
abstract: This opera based on a short story by Judy Budnitz will be performed at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts Jan. 9-11.
lead_paragraph: For new music, the main difficulty isn’t getting a premiere. It’s getting a second performance, and a third, and a fourth, the repetitions necessary for a piece really to enter the cultural bloodstream.

headline: More Hillary Clinton Emails Are Released, but State Department Falls Short
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: More messages are disclosed, but officials fail to meet a judge’s requirement to produce 82 percent of her emails by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department fell short of a court order requiring the release of the vast bulk of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s emails by the end of 2015, but promised on Thursday to catch up early in the new year.

headline: Review: In Barb Choit’s ‘Pronk,’ 1980s Shoes Are Back
abstract: Ms. Choit’s show at Rawson Projects raises questions about the overlapping of art and advertising.

headline: Review: ‘Only Yesterday,’ Isao Takahata’s Time-Jumping Anime
abstract: Mr. Takahata’s 1991 feature about a woman and her younger self gets a new voice cast (including Daisy Ridley) for its release in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Isao Takahata, an Academy Award nominee and one of the twin pillars of the anime giant Studio Ghibli, brings the cleareyed grace of his animation to the lovely memoiristic story of a 27-year-old woman in “Only Yesterday.” As the woman, Taeko, goes on a vacation in the country that brings back grade-school memories, Mr. Takahata finds a poignancy in milestones and ordinary moments alike, showing her sense of self deepening over time.

headline: Review: Nathaniel Robinson’s Sculptures Tease Perceptions
abstract: His show at Launch F18 plays in the gap between what viewers see and what they understand.
lead_paragraph: The remarkably inventive sculptor Nathaniel Robinson makes technically impressive, philosophically provocative works that play in the gap between perception and cognition — between what you see and what you understand.

headline: Site of a Raging Fire in Downtown Dubai
abstract: A 63-story luxury hotel in Dubai caught on fire Thursday evening, interrupting New Year’s Eve celebrations.
lead_paragraph: A 63-story luxury hotel in Dubai caught on fire Thursday evening, interrupting New Year’s Eve celebrations.

headline: Review: In ‘Other People’s Children,’ a Woman’s Pain and Search for Artistic Solace
abstract: A self-destructive filmmaker walks cluelessly toward her own undoing as she tries to make a documentary about people who live on the streets.
lead_paragraph: “Other People’s Children,” a painfully hackneyed first feature by the director Liz Hinlein, is doomed from the outset by its wearisome heroine, Sam (Diane Marshall-Green). Appearing in almost every scene, Sam — a filmmaker who has “victim” practically stenciled on her forehead — drifts vapidly through downtown Los Angeles, trying to untangle her feelings about her recently deceased father by engaging in mindless sex and binge drinking.

headline: Making a Show From Found Videos, Both Unsettling and Lighthearted
abstract: The resulting work, “The Art of Luv (Part One): Elliot” by the Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble at the Under the Radar festival, is an experimental blend of technology and genre.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows the YouTube sensations, the most popular cats and kiddos. But Sean McElroy and Tei Blow, the avant-garde theater duo who make up Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble, were after the opposite: YouTube videos with almost no audience.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Jan. 1-7
abstract: Sometimes only a few days separate Christmas cheer from cabin fever. For families who’ve grown tired of staying at home, Brooklyn Botanic Garden offers a weekend event in which colorful paper and pungent pine have nothing to do with the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes only a few days separate Christmas cheer from cabin fever. For families who’ve grown tired of staying at home, Brooklyn Botanic Garden offers a weekend event in which colorful paper and pungent pine have nothing to do with the holidays.

headline: A Year of Mourning Steeped in African Tradition Leads to a Theater Piece
abstract: Kaneza Schaal’s mourning for her father’s death led her to create “Go Forth,” a performance and installation piece opening at Westbeth Artists Community.
lead_paragraph: Kaneza Schaal was 25 when her father died of malaria in 2010. Her first impulse was to stay in New York, not fly to the funeral in Burundi, where he lived when he wasn’t in the East Village. At the time, she was working with immigrant students at a school in Chelsea, and she saw no reason to interrupt that.

headline: Review: In ‘Yosemite,’ a Coming-of-Age Tale of 3 Boys in 1980s California
abstract: Gabrielle Demeestere’s debut feature is adapted in part from stories by James Franco, who is a co-star in the movie.
lead_paragraph: The young French-born filmmaker Gabrielle Demeestere can be an observant and resourceful simulator of lovely small moments. There’s a brief sequence in her debut feature, “Yosemite” (adapted in part from a couple of stories by its executive producer and co-star James Franco), in which a boy wakes up in the morning to find a spider walking up his bedroom curtain. He cups it in his hands, examines it, and some of his wonder and curiosity make their way off the screen.

headline: BTG Pactual Sells Distressed Debt Unit to Itau Unibanco
abstract: The investment firm is on an aggressive campaign to sell assets after the arrest of its founder and former chief, André Esteves.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s largest private sector banking group said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the distressed debt unit of the troubled investment firm BTG Pactual for about 1.2 billion reais, or about $307 million.

headline: A Desert Biennial Alongside Coachella Is in the Works
abstract: Desert X, as the show is to be called, will invite artists to respond to the California desert’s history, geology or mythology, or otherwise to create site-specific works.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Ed Ruscha and friends threw a Royal typewriter out the window of a speeding Buick LeSabre near Los Angeles for his 1967 photographic book, “Royal Road Test,” the impact of the California desert has been visible in his work. Now, Mr. Ruscha is part of an effort to establish a biennial-like exhibition in the Palm Springs area that would be timed for February through April 2017 to overlap with Modernism Week and the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, two big crowd-pleasers.

headline: Review: Phish Settles In for Another New Year’s Run
abstract: The band, whose concerts take on their own narratives, myths and rituals, opened a four-night stretch Wednesday at Madison Square Garden, one of its most played venues.
lead_paragraph: Phish began its semi-regular New Year’s run at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the first of its four straight nights of shows there. The concerts are sold out. If you don’t have a ticket and don’t follow Phish, it means that you’ll see excitable, woodsy-looking men with beards in Midtown bars before 7:30 and after 11:30 p.m. The concerts will in no other way affect you. They do not intersect with contemporary aesthetics or dynamic social currents.

headline: Response to Paris Attacks Points to Weaknesses in French Police Structure
abstract: Accounts from survivors, officials and experts reveal that the terrorists operated for substantial periods with little hindrance, and that France’s top-heavy chain of command contributed to delays.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Since the devastating Nov. 13 attacks in Paris, the French police have offered only a fragmentary outline of their response and of how they deployed antiterror teams and other forces. The somberness and solidarity in the weeks since have muted public criticism. No review of the police’s performance has been announced.

headline: Review: For the Crawleys and ‘Downton Abbey,’ the Beginning of the End
abstract: The sixth and final season of Julian Fellowes’s wildly popular drama about the British aristocracy and their employees begins this weekend on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Downton Abbey — the country house, if not the wildly popular PBS drama — begins the show’s final season on Sunday night in a depleted state. Servants are not being replaced, and Robert Crawley, the Earl of Grantham, is hinting that further reductions may be needed. Upstairs, both Tom Branson and Rose MacClare (now Lady Rose Aldridge) have sailed for America, taking with them some of the show’s energy and audience good will. When the Granthams gather in the morning, it’s a sad showing, just Robert, Mary and Edith around a small table.

headline: Review: Drips, Dropped: Pollock and His Impact
abstract: “Jackson Pollock: A Collection Survey, 1934-1954” and “Take an Object” at MoMA show how the artist’s style developed as well as its influence on those who came after.
lead_paragraph: Any exhibition of older art drawn from a museum’s permanent collection is a palm held out for us to read, a snapshot of the museum’s sense of its role over time, its present ambitions and its view of art history. Place two such exhibitions side by side and an especially intense and revealing frisson can occur.

headline: A Times Course for Young World Changers Asks, ‘Sustain What?’
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Education (K-12)', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Sustainable Living', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: High school students learn about climate science and sustainable development at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Most visitors know I left full-time journalism in 2010 to teach courses on communication and environmental policy at Pace University. But you may not know that The Times, itself, is expanding its mission beyond traditional journalism and, with a partner, has launched The School of The New York Times, offering mini-courses on weekends to high school and older middle school students and courses for professionals in various fields. There’ll soon be online classes and much more.

headline: Hostage at Bataclan Recalls Terrorists During Paris Attack
abstract: A 23-year-old photographer from Chile described the strange chuckle of one of the terrorists as he continued to fire into the crowd.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He was one of a dozen-odd hostages captured by a group of terrorists as they finished their massacre in November at the Bataclan, living for over two hours in their grip in a narrow upstairs corridor at the Paris concert hall and then through the final assault of the police as bullets flew.

abstract: Photos from South Korea, Tokyo, Switzerland and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Korea, Tokyo, Switzerland and Turkey.

headline: Decrease in Homeless Veterans in New York Far Outpaces National Drop
abstract: Even as homelessness has surged, the city has recorded a drop of 80 percent in the number of veterans living in shelters or on the street since 2009 — though some advocates question the counts.
lead_paragraph: The bedraggled veteran draped in a flag, begging for spare change, has been one of the most persistent images of homelessness in this country.

headline: Television This Winter: 20 Shows to Keep on Your Radar Screen
abstract: A preview of new and returning television arriving over the next three months.
lead_paragraph: “AMERICAN CRIME,” “American Crime Story, “The Americans” — the winter season of new and returning television shows has a patriotic sound to it (setting aside that the shows in question are about rape, murder and Soviet espionage). And you can throw in a PBS drama actually set in America, “Mercy Street”; an alternate history of an American tragedy, “11.22.63”; and the return of an American classic, “The X-Files.” Here are 20 shows to watch for during the next three months.

headline: Microsoft to Notify Users of Government Hackings
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: The company joins Google, Facebook and others in disclosing when users of email and other services have probably been targeted by hackers working on behalf of governments.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft says it will begin notifying users of its online services if they have been targets of suspected state-sponsored online attacks, joining a growing list of Internet companies stepping up their security policies with similar measures.

headline: Gun-Friendly Texas Is Getting Even Friendlier
abstract: On Friday, a new law took effect that allows Texans with permits to carry concealed weapons to openly carry those weapons.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Texas is so gun-friendly that it is easier to get into the Capitol in Austin with a firearm than without one — licensed, gun-carrying lawmakers and members of the public have their own no-wait security lane, and the unarmed masses have to stand in line and slog through the metal detectors.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Supporting Ted Cruz Plan a $1 Million Advertising Buy
abstract: Allied “super PACs” supporting Mr. Cruz’s presidential campaign plan the television, digital and radio advertising buy in the early voting states, with the heaviest spending in Iowa, a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: A string of allied “super PACs” supporting the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is planning a $1 million television, digital and radio advertising buy in the early voting states, with the heaviest spending in Iowa, a spokeswoman for the group said.

headline: A Family in Transition Rebuilds Its Connections
abstract: Karen Quinones was overwhelmed and scrambling to take care of her four children, two of whom have pervasive developmental disorder, when she ended an unhealthy relationship.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Quinones’s son Tristian was almost 3 years old, a New Jersey Transit driver stopped the bus in the middle of the Lincoln Tunnel and pleaded with her to stop her son’s crying. He said the tantrum was so distracting that he could not drive.

headline: Chief Justice’s Report Praises Limits on Litigants’ Access to Information
abstract: Others are not pleased with the adoption of limits on the pretrial exchange of facts that lawyers call discovery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Calling for “a change in our legal culture,” Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. devoted his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary to a plea that lawyers “avoid antagonistic tactics, wasteful procedural maneuvers and teetering brinkmanship.”

headline: A Roller Coaster Year Ends With U.S. Markets Mostly Down
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: A three-year rally was followed by a lackluster performance in 2015 but, given the year’s headwinds, it could have been worse.
lead_paragraph: Investors may be disappointed with the lackluster performance of the United States stock market in 2015, but, given all that happened, it could have been worse.
